additional_notes: Used to express frustration or irritation with something or someone. It's similar to other expressions that show annoyance.
target_language_example: Este trabajo de las narices me tiene cansado.
native_language_example: This darn job has me tired.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to describe something that happens or is done exactly as theory or rules dictate. It's often used in colloquial speech to point out that something is predictable or behaves as expected in an ideal scenario.
target_language_example: Ese penal fue de libro.
native_language_example: That penalty was textbook.

meaning: from one plain (flat area) to the next
additional_notes: Used mainly in narrative or poetic contexts to evoke continuous travel across flat countryside. Not common in everyday conversation.
target_language_example: El arriero avanzaba de llano en llano hasta llegar al río.
native_language_example: The muleteer kept moving from one plain to the next until he reached the river.

additional_notes: Introduces what will happen if the preceding statement is not true. Often set off by commas.
target_language_example: Llega temprano, de lo contrario perderás el autobús.
native_language_example: Arrive early; otherwise you’ll miss the bus.

additional_notes: Used to describe something as being of very high quality or top-notch. It can refer to people, objects, or experiences.
target_language_example: El concierto fue de lo mejor que he visto este año.
native_language_example: The concert was the best I've seen this year.

additional_notes: Placed before an adjective or adverb to strongly emphasize it, much like "really" or "super" in English. Common in informal speech and writing.
target_language_example: La película fue de lo más divertida.
native_language_example: The movie was extremely funny.

additional_notes: Used after verbs/adjectives that take the preposition "de" or after comparatives. The neuter "lo" refers to an unspecified idea or thing, not a masculine noun.
target_language_example: Sé más de lo que piensas.
native_language_example: I know more than you think.

additional_notes: Often used informally to express amazement, disbelief, or to emphasize something extraordinary. It can apply to both unexpected good or bad situations.
target_language_example: ¡Esta fiesta es de locos!
native_language_example: This party is crazy!

additional_notes: 'De lujo' is used to describe something that is impressive and of high quality or luxurious. It can apply to objects, experiences, or even actions that are done with excellence.
target_language_example: ¡Ese coche es de lujo!
native_language_example: That car is luxurious!

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used when someone is grieving the death of a loved one. It's a way to express the period of mourning or the emotional state following a loss. It can also be used metaphorically to describe a somber or sorrowful mood.
target_language_example: Ella está de luto por su abuela.
native_language_example: She is in mourning for her grandmother.

additional_notes: Used to describe events or actions that occur in the early hours before the usual start of the day, often from midnight to dawn.
target_language_example: Salimos de madrugada para llegar temprano.
native_language_example: We left early in the morning to arrive early.

additional_notes: Used when a situation is deteriorating or getting progressively worse. It's an idiom often used to describe the escalation of negative circumstances.
target_language_example: Después del accidente, las cosas fueron de mal en peor.
native_language_example: After the accident, things went from bad to worse.

additional_notes: Often used to describe actions done without eagerness or enthusiasm, typically because someone feels obligated or pressured.
target_language_example: Juan aceptó la invitación de mala gana.
native_language_example: Juan accepted the invitation reluctantly.

meaning: in a bad mood or unlucky.
additional_notes: This expression is often used colloquially to imply that someone is having an unlucky time or is in a grumpy mood. It is informal and typically found in conversational Spanish.
target_language_example: Hoy estoy de malas, todo me sale mal.
native_language_example: Today I'm in a bad mood, everything is going wrong for me.

additional_notes: Describes something being passed around sequentially among people, like a flyer, book, or rumor.
target_language_example: El cuaderno fue pasando de mano en mano hasta llegar al profesor.
native_language_example: The notebook went from hand to hand until it reached the teacher.

additional_notes: Often used to express how well something is going or how great something is, such as someone's mood, the outcome of an event, or overall feelings.
target_language_example: La fiesta estuvo de maravilla.
native_language_example: The party was marvelous.

additional_notes: It is commonly used to indicate that something is happening excellently or beyond just fine. Often used in casual conversation in response to questions about one's well-being or how something is going.
target_language_example: Todo va de maravillas en el nuevo proyecto.
native_language_example: Everything is going wonderfully with the new project.

additional_notes: It can be used to refer to actions or events that occur in the morning or things associated with the morning time.
target_language_example: Tengo una reunión de mañana.
native_language_example: I have a meeting in the morning.

meaning: 'through the corner of your eye' or 'sidelong'.
additional_notes: Used when observing someone or something discreetly or with suspicion, often without turning one's head toward the subject fully.
target_language_example: Me miraba de medio ojo mientras hablaba con otros.
native_language_example: He was looking at me out of the corner of his eye while talking to others.

additional_notes: Used after verbs (e.g., saber, aprender, recitar) to indicate knowing or performing something without reading or referring to notes.
target_language_example: Me sé este poema de memoria.
native_language_example: I know this poem by heart.

additional_notes: This term is often applied to objects or situations that are not real, such as toy items, fictional stories, or imaginary scenarios. It helps learners identify and describe things that are intended for play or imaginative purposes.
target_language_example: Este anillo es de mentira, solo es un juguete.
native_language_example: This ring is fake, it's just a toy.

additional_notes: Often used as a term of endearment to express deep affection for someone. It implies that the person is a vital part of your life.
target_language_example: Te amo, amor de mi vida.
native_language_example: I love you, love of my life.

additional_notes: Commonly used informally to mean something is fantastic or excellent. Can also literally mean something is scary or causes fear, depending on context.
target_language_example: La película fue de miedo.
native_language_example: The movie was fantastic.

additional_notes: It is considered a vulgar expression, used to strongly emphasize something poorly done or of low quality. It's often used in informal settings, and learners should be aware of its vulgarity when using it.
target_language_example: Ese coche es de mierda.
native_language_example: That car is shitty.

additional_notes: Used to express that something happened against all odds, or in an unexpected and fortunate manner. Often used when something almost didn’t happen.
target_language_example: Llegué a tiempo de milagro.
native_language_example: I arrived on time by chance.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe clothing, objects, or concepts that are considered trendy or popular at the current time.
target_language_example: Ese vestido está de moda este verano.
native_language_example: That dress is in fashion this summer.

meaning: 'so that' or 'in such a way that'.
additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used to express cause-and-effect or purpose. It helps link two clauses where the first explains a condition or manner, and the second describes an outcome or goal.
target_language_example: Estudió mucho, de modo que aprobó el examen.
native_language_example: He studied a lot, so that he passed the exam.

additional_notes: Used when a situation is currently one way but may change. It's a way to express a temporary state or decision.
target_language_example: De momento, no hay cambios en el horario.
native_language_example: For now, there are no changes in the schedule.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe food that is exceptionally good or an experience that is particularly enjoyable. It's an informal and emphatic way to praise.
target_language_example: ¡Este pastel está de muerte!
native_language_example: This cake is to die for!

additional_notes: Used to describe something that exceeds what is necessary, often implying waste or surplus.
target_language_example: Hay un tenedor de más en la mesa.
native_language_example: There is an extra fork on the table.

de mírame y no me toques

target_language_multi_word_term: de mírame y no me toques
additional_notes: Colloquial expression. Often placed after the verb "ser" to highlight how fragile, finicky, or over-sensitive a person or object is.
target_language_example: Su carácter es de mírame y no me toques: se enfada por cualquier cosa.
native_language_example: His personality is so touchy—he gets upset about anything.

additional_notes: Used to describe traits, characteristics, or origins that are inherent since birth.
target_language_example: Él es zurdo de nacimiento.
native_language_example: He is left-handed from birth.

additional_notes: Used after someone says 'thank you', similar to saying 'it's nothing'. Common in everyday interactions.
target_language_example: - Gracias por tu ayuda. - De nada.
native_language_example: - Thanks for your help. - You're welcome.

additional_notes: Used informally to express a high degree of something, whether positive or negative. For example, if someone did something very well or something went spectacularly wrong.
target_language_example: La fiesta estuvo de narices.
native_language_example: The party was extremely good.

meaning: out of necessity; because it was necessary
additional_notes: Placed after the verb or noun it qualifies. Emphasizes that an action or item is driven by basic need rather than preference.
target_language_example: Lo hizo de necesidad, no por gusto.
native_language_example: He did it out of necessity, not for pleasure.

additional_notes: Often used to respond firmly to suggestions, proposals, or statements that one wants to strongly deny or disagree with.
target_language_example: ¿Me prestarías tu coche? - ¡De ninguna manera!
native_language_example: Can I borrow your car? - No way!

additional_notes: Used to emphasize a strong refusal or negation, often in response to a suggestion or statement that one disagrees with or wants to negate completely.
target_language_example: De ningún modo voy a ir a esa fiesta.
native_language_example: I am by no means going to that party.

additional_notes: Used to specify the time of day something is happening, particularly in contrast to 'de día,' which means 'during the day'.
target_language_example: Salen de noche a caminar.
native_language_example: They go for a walk at night.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to talk about what typically happens or what is usually the case. It's common in discussions about habits and expectations.
target_language_example: De normal, me levanto a las siete de la mañana.
native_language_example: Usually, I get up at seven in the morning.

additional_notes: Used to describe something that feels interminable or excessively long, often with a negative connotation.
target_language_example: El tráfico aquí es un problema de nunca acabar.
native_language_example: The traffic here is a never-ending problem.

meaning: by fiat / because I say so.
additional_notes: Used to describe decisions or rules imposed unilaterally, stressing lack of discussion or democracy. Slightly informal and critical in tone.
target_language_example: El jefe cambió el horario de trabajo de ordeno y mando.
native_language_example: The boss changed the work schedule just because he felt like it (by fiat).

additional_notes: Used to describe something that happens regularly or is customary.
target_language_example: De ordinario, él toma café por la mañana.
native_language_example: He usually drinks coffee in the morning.

additional_notes: Used after a noun to specify that it features or is made of the two colors/materials gold and blue. Common in descriptions of flags, sports uniforms, jewelry, etc.
target_language_example: El equipo viste una camiseta de oro y azul.
native_language_example: The team wears a gold-and-blue jersey.

additional_notes: Used to suggest an alternative manner or condition, often introducing a possible consequence if the initial condition is not met.
target_language_example: Termina el proyecto hoy, de otro modo perderás el bono.
native_language_example: Finish the project today, otherwise you will lose the bonus.

additional_notes: Commonly used for musicians and language learners who can replicate or understand something based solely on listening, without needing written material.
target_language_example: Aprendió a tocar la guitarra de oído.
native_language_example: He learned to play the guitar by ear.

de padre y muy señor mío

target_language_multi_word_term: de padre y muy señor mío
additional_notes: Colloquial intensifier usually placed after ‘un/una’ + noun to stress how big or serious something is. Rough English equivalents: “massive,” “huge,” “one heck of a…”.
target_language_example: Montaron un lío de padre y muy señor mío.
native_language_example: They made one heck of a mess.

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used in contexts where someone is delivering a message, gift, or action as a representative or on someone else’s instructions.
target_language_example: Este regalo es de parte de María.
native_language_example: This gift is from Maria.

meaning: 'at the same time' or 'by the way'.
additional_notes: 'De paso' is used when mentioning an action that is done in addition to the main action, often to take advantage of the current circumstances.
target_language_example: Fui al mercado y de paso compré pan.
native_language_example: I went to the market and bought bread at the same time.

additional_notes: Commonly used in religious contexts or to describe something that is considered morally wrong or sinful.
target_language_example: El acto fue considerado un acto de pecado.
native_language_example: The act was considered an act of sin.

additional_notes: Used to describe something as exceptionally good, spectacular, or thrilling, akin to scenes from a movie.
target_language_example: La fiesta fue de película.
native_language_example: The party was like something out of a movie.

additional_notes: Used to describe someone or something seen or positioned from the side, especially in photos or physical orientation.
target_language_example: En la foto salgo de perfil.
native_language_example: In the photo I appear in profile.

additional_notes: Used informally to convey satisfaction or the ideal suitability of something, akin to 'like a charm'.
target_language_example: La decoración quedó de perlas.
native_language_example: The decoration turned out perfectly.

meaning: 'of dogs', implying something unpleasant or bad.
additional_notes: Commonly used to describe bad weather or poor conditions, like a figurative way to say something is as unpleasant as a 'dog's day'.
target_language_example: El clima está de perros hoy.
native_language_example: The weather is awful today.

meaning: from one person to another; individually.
additional_notes: Use it to stress direct personal interaction or variability based on each individual. Similar to the English “from person to person” or “one-on-one.”
target_language_example: El efecto del medicamento cambia de persona a persona.
native_language_example: The effect of the medicine varies from person to person.

additional_notes: 'De peso' is frequently used to describe something that carries significant influence or importance, not necessarily tied to physical weight.
target_language_example: Su opinión es de mucho peso en la empresa.
native_language_example: His opinion carries a lot of weight in the company.

additional_notes: Used to describe someone who is upright on their feet, not seated or lying down. Often follows verbs of movement or state of being such as 'estar' (to be).
target_language_example: El profesor está de pie en el aula.
native_language_example: The teacher is standing in the classroom.

additional_notes: Used to describe something physically made from stone or metaphorically to describe something or someone as emotionally hard or cold.
target_language_example: Tiene una casa de piedra en el campo.
native_language_example: He has a stone house in the countryside.

additional_notes: Typically used to specify measurement or something related to feet, like height or length. Context may vary, sometimes referring to movement by foot: 'a pie'.
target_language_example: El árbol mide 15 metros de pies.
native_language_example: The tree measures 15 meters in feet.

additional_notes: Used to describe something that is done thoroughly, covering every part or detail, often related to physical coverage or examination.
target_language_example: Estaba vestido de pies a cabeza en ropa de invierno.
native_language_example: He was dressed from head to toe in winter clothing.

additional_notes: Commonly used in contexts involving law or belonging, to express a full entitlement or status under law or rules.
target_language_example: Es ciudadano de pleno derecho.
native_language_example: He is a full-fledged citizen.

additional_notes: Typically used to describe a person who doesn't talk much or prefers to speak only when necessary.
target_language_example: Mi abuelo es un hombre de pocas palabras.
native_language_example: My grandfather is a man of few words.

additional_notes: Used to indicate a general or nonspecific location, often when the exact place is not known or not important.
target_language_example: El libro es de por ahí, lo encontré en la casa.
native_language_example: The book is from around there, I found it at the house.

additional_notes: Used when something or someone is in the middle of a situation or process, often implying involvement or interference.
target_language_example: No quiero problemas con dinero de por medio.
native_language_example: I don't want problems with money involved.

additional_notes: Highlights an inherent quality or a pre-existing condition, often used to stress that no further justification is needed.
target_language_example: La ciudad es cara de por sí, y en temporada alta es aún peor.
native_language_example: The city is expensive in itself, and in high season it’s even worse.

additional_notes: Often used to describe commitments or guarantees meant to be lifelong. It can also refer to a condition or situation that is permanent.
target_language_example: Tengo una garantía de por vida para mi reloj.
native_language_example: I have a lifetime guarantee for my watch.

additional_notes: Appears after the noun to specify that the item performs with great exactness, similar to "precision" as an adjective in English (e.g., precision tools, precision surgery).
target_language_example: Necesitamos instrumentos de precisión para este experimento.
native_language_example: We need precision instruments for this experiment.

additional_notes: Informal praise for superior quality. Usually follows the noun: "comida de primera" or after a verb: "La película estuvo de primera."
target_language_example: El servicio en ese hotel es de primera.
native_language_example: The service at that hotel is top-notch.

meaning: for the first course / as a starter
additional_notes: Common in restaurants offering a fixed-price menu with several courses. You say what you’ll have "de primero" (starter) and then "de segundo" (main).
target_language_example: De primero quiero la sopa, por favor.
native_language_example: For the starter I’d like the soup, please.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to indicate urgency or the need for speed in a particular action or situation. It's similar to saying 'hurry up' in English.
target_language_example: Ella salió de prisa para no perder el autobús.
native_language_example: She left quickly to not miss the bus.

additional_notes: Used to describe actions or events that occur without prior warning or prediction. Often used to highlight a change or shift in situation or state.
target_language_example: De pronto, comenzó a llover.
native_language_example: Suddenly, it started to rain.

additional_notes: It is commonly used in contexts like software or services that are on trial, or when a sample is given out to be tested or tried by users.
target_language_example: Esta es una versión de prueba del software.
native_language_example: This is a trial version of the software.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to express that something is the way it appears to others, but not necessarily the whole truth or how it is internally or privately.
target_language_example: De puertas para afuera, todo parece perfecto, pero en realidad tienen muchos problemas.
native_language_example: Outwardly, everything seems perfect, but in reality, they have many problems.

additional_notes: Often used in phrases like 'poner los pelos de punta' (to give goosebumps) or 'estar de punta' referring to something or someone being tense or erect.
target_language_example: Esa película me puso los pelos de punta.
native_language_example: That movie gave me goosebumps.

additional_notes: Used to stress that every part or detail of something is covered, similar to “from top to bottom” or “from cover to cover.”
target_language_example: Revisaron la casa de punta a cabo.
native_language_example: They inspected the house from top to bottom.

meaning: from end to end; all the way across.
additional_notes: Indicates covering something in its entirety, literally or figuratively. Often paired with verbs like recorrer, leer, or limpiar.
target_language_example: Viajamos de punta a punta por la costa.
native_language_example: We traveled from one end of the coast to the other.

additional_notes: Used when referring to someone moving quietly or discreetly, typically by walking on the balls of their feet to avoid making noise.
target_language_example: Entré en la habitación de puntillas para no despertarte.
native_language_example: I entered the room on tiptoes so as not to wake you.

additional_notes: This term is often used to describe garments that are made from a knitted fabric, like sweaters or other knitwear. It indicates the material or style of the clothing item.
target_language_example: Ella llevaba un suéter de punto azul.
native_language_example: She was wearing a blue knitted sweater.

additional_notes: This phrase is informal and can be considered vulgar. It is often used among friends or in casual settings and can be both positive or strong in certain contexts, depending on tone.
target_language_example: La fiesta estuvo de puta madre.
native_language_example: The party was amazing.

additional_notes: It is often used to emphasize that a document or message was personally written by the individual, rather than typed or ghostwritten, thus asserting its authenticity or personal significance.
target_language_example: El contrato fue firmado de puño y letra por el director.
native_language_example: The contract was signed by the director's own hand.

additional_notes: Often used to describe clothes, jewelry, or other objects that can be easily removed or switched out.
target_language_example: Este collar es de quita y pon, perfecto para cambiar de estilo rápidamente.
native_language_example: This necklace is detachable, perfect for changing styles quickly.

additional_notes: This phrase is typically used to indicate that something, often an animal like a dog or horse, possesses qualities or characteristics typical of a specific breed. It highlights purity or distinguished origin.
target_language_example: Es un perro de raza.
native_language_example: It is a purebred dog.

additional_notes: Depending on the context, 'de reparto' can refer to the distribution of goods or services, or it can refer to the cast of a play or film, meaning the supporting cast.
target_language_example: El camión de reparto llegará mañana por la mañana.
native_language_example: The delivery truck will arrive tomorrow morning.

additional_notes: Used to describe an action or event that occurs quickly and without warning. Often used in storytelling to introduce an unexpected event.
target_language_example: De repente, comenzó a llover muy fuerte.
native_language_example: Suddenly, it started raining very hard.

additional_notes: Used to describe items that serve as replacements or backups for primary ones.
target_language_example: Tengo una llanta de repuesto en el baúl del coche.
native_language_example: I have a spare tire in the trunk of the car.

additional_notes: Placed after a noun to show that the item is a back-up kept for later or emergency use.
target_language_example: Siempre llevo una batería de reserva para mi cámara.
native_language_example: I always carry a spare battery for my camera.

additional_notes: This phrase is typically used in more formal contexts to indicate the cause of something. It's similar to other causative phrases like 'debido a' or 'a causa de'.
target_language_example: El proyecto se retrasó de resultas de la falta de financiación.
native_language_example: The project was delayed as a result of the lack of funding.

additional_notes: Used to describe when someone is physically kneeling down. It can also imply humility or submission, both literally and figuratively.
target_language_example: Se puso de rodillas para pedir perdón.
native_language_example: He got on his knees to ask for forgiveness.

additional_notes: Typically used to describe actions that are undertaken without public knowledge or are intentionally hidden.
target_language_example: Hicieron la reunión de secreto.
native_language_example: They held the meeting in secret.

additional_notes: The term is often used to describe objects that are not new, such as clothes, cars, or items in general. It can also refer to quality, suggesting something is not top-tier or is of lower quality.
target_language_example: Compré un coche de segunda, pero está en buen estado.
native_language_example: I bought a second-hand car, but it's in good condition.

additional_notes: Often used when talking about goods like clothing, books, or cars. Indicative of previous ownership or use.
target_language_example: Compré un coche de segunda mano.
native_language_example: I bought a second-hand car.

additional_notes: Expresses certainty or affirmation. In different contexts, it can also refer to insurance, but this meaning is less common in day-to-day conversation.
target_language_example: Él vendrá de seguro a la fiesta.
native_language_example: He will surely come to the party.

additional_notes: Often seen in formal or specific contexts where something is designated for use by staff or particular functions. It can be used to describe rooms, vehicles, or items intended for servicing purposes.
target_language_example: Esta es la entrada de servicio para el personal.
native_language_example: This is the service entrance for the staff.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to indicate that there is a surplus or excess of something, often implying that it's more than what is necessary.
target_language_example: Tenemos comida de sobra para la fiesta.
native_language_example: We have more than enough food for the party.

meaning: from dawn to dusk; all day long
additional_notes: Used to emphasize long, continuous effort or activity throughout the daylight hours, especially labor.
target_language_example: Trabajamos de sol a sol para terminar la cosecha.
native_language_example: We worked from dawn to dusk to finish the harvest.

meaning: one-on-one; privately, just the two of us.
additional_notes: Used to emphasize that only the two people involved will be present—no audience, no intermediaries. Can refer to a private talk or a direct confrontation.
target_language_example: Necesito hablar contigo de solo a solo.
native_language_example: I need to talk to you one-on-one.

additional_notes: This phrase implies that something is a natural characteristic or intrinsic quality of a person or thing without external influence.
target_language_example: Ese comportamiento es de suyo.
native_language_example: That behavior is inherent.

meaning: once in a while / every now and then
additional_notes: Used to describe something that happens infrequently. Synonyms: "de vez en cuando," "de cuando en cuando." Sounds a bit more formal or poetic than the synonyms but is understood everywhere.
target_language_example: De tarde en tarde visito a mis abuelos.
native_language_example: I visit my grandparents every now and then.

additional_notes: Commonly used in the context of food, such as fruits and vegetables, but can also apply to fashion or other seasonal trends.
target_language_example: Me encanta comer frutas de temporada.
native_language_example: I love eating fruits that are in season.

additional_notes: The phrase is often used to describe something that is not of high quality or is seen as less important. It can be used in various contexts, such as describing a hotel, a product, or even someone's behavior.
target_language_example: Ese hotel es de tercera categoría.
native_language_example: That hotel is third-class.

additional_notes: This expression is used to refer to something that has existed for a long time, often with a sense of nostalgia or tradition. It implies consistency or the idea of something being enduring and familiar.
target_language_example: Vamos al restaurante de toda la vida este fin de semana.
native_language_example: We're going to the traditional/restaurant we always go to this weekend.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that something said or done remains true or occurs regardless of any other factors.
target_language_example: No me siento bien hoy, pero de todas formas iré a la reunión.
native_language_example: I don't feel well today, but I will go to the meeting anyway.

additional_notes: It's used to emphasize that something will happen regardless of circumstances. It can express disregard for opposing factors, or mark a return to the main topic after a digression.
target_language_example: No quería ir, pero de todas maneras fui.
native_language_example: I didn't want to go, but I went anyway.

additional_notes: Used to express sincerity and strong emotion when stating intentions or sentiments. Commonly found in expressions of gratitude, love, or sincere plans and promises.
target_language_example: Te agradezco de todo corazón por tu ayuda.
native_language_example: I thank you wholeheartedly for your help.

de todo hay en la viña del Señor

target_language_multi_word_term: de todo hay en la viña del Señor
meaning: there are all kinds of people/things in the world
additional_notes: Used to express acceptance or mild surprise at the variety of human behavior or situations; similar to "it takes all sorts" or "there's nowt so queer as folk."
target_language_example: Dicen que vive con siete gatos y dos serpientes; de todo hay en la viña del Señor.
native_language_example: They say he lives with seven cats and two snakes; it takes all sorts.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used in more formal contexts to stress the total extent or degree of something, similar to saying 'completely' in English.
target_language_example: La resolución fue de todo punto injusta.
native_language_example: The decision was completely unfair.

additional_notes: It is used to express that an action or state will occur regardless of other circumstances. Often employed to conclude a discussion or emphasize that a decision will stand despite differing opinions.
target_language_example: No quería ir a la fiesta, pero, de todos modos, fui.
native_language_example: I didn't want to go to the party, but I went anyway.

meaning: major; of great importance or magnitude
additional_notes: Colloquial intensifier placed after a noun to emphasize its seriousness, size, or impact (e.g., un problema de tomo y lomo).
target_language_example: Lo que ocurrió fue un escándalo de tomo y lomo.
native_language_example: What happened was a major scandal.

meaning: of little value or low quality.
additional_notes: This expression can describe objects, people, or situations that are considered trivial or of inferior quality. It is often used to critique or diminish something.
target_language_example: Ese coche es un modelo de tres al cuarto.
native_language_example: That car is a cheap model.

additional_notes: It is often used to describe items, areas, or offices involved in the process of moving people or goods, such as "oficina de tránsito" (transit office) or "señal de tránsito" (traffic sign).
target_language_example: La oficina de tránsito está cerrada hoy.
native_language_example: The transit office is closed today.

meaning: overnight; suddenly from one day to the next.
additional_notes: Used to emphasize that a change happens very quickly with little or no warning.
target_language_example: La empresa cerró de un día para otro.
native_language_example: The company closed overnight.

additional_notes: Used to describe actions that occur abruptly, all at once, or with a sudden impact.
target_language_example: Completó el rompecabezas de un golpe.
native_language_example: He completed the puzzle in one go.

additional_notes: Used to describe movement between different places or a state of being busy. Often implies a hectic or disorganized situation involving frequent changes in location.
target_language_example: He estado toda la mañana moviéndome de un lado para otro.
native_language_example: I've been moving back and forth all morning.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to assert that something will be done or happen by any available means. It's often used to show determination or to imply that the specific method does not matter, as long as the outcome is achieved.
target_language_example: Voy a conseguir el trabajo, de un modo u otro.
native_language_example: I'm going to get the job, one way or another.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to express the expectation of an imminent event that could happen without warning. It implies an element of surprise or anticipation.
target_language_example: La lluvia empezó de un momento a otro.
native_language_example: The rain started at any moment.

de un tiempo a esta parte

target_language_multi_word_term: de un tiempo a esta parte
additional_notes: Used to indicate that something has been happening or has changed over a period leading up to now. It can be used in both casual and formal conversations.
target_language_example: De un tiempo a esta parte, he estado yendo al gimnasio con más frecuencia.
native_language_example: For some time now, I've been going to the gym more frequently.

additional_notes: Signals an ongoing situation that started in the recent past and is still true. Often placed at the start of a sentence.
target_language_example: De un tiempo para acá, he estado haciendo más ejercicio.
native_language_example: For some time now, I've been working out more.

meaning: all at once, in one go.
additional_notes: Often used to describe completing a task or activity without breaks or interruptions.
target_language_example: Se leyó el libro de un tirón.
native_language_example: She read the book all at once.

additional_notes: Very informal. Often used as an exclamation to show eagerness or agreement to do something without delay; can also mean "in one go".
target_language_example: ¿Vamos al cine ahora? — ¡De una!
native_language_example: Shall we go to the movies now? — Right away!

additional_notes: Used to describe a person who is straightforward, sincere, or morally intact. It can imply stability in character, suggesting that the person does not waver in their values.
target_language_example: Es un hombre de una pieza, siempre dice la verdad.
native_language_example: He is an honest man, he always tells the truth.

additional_notes: Used to convey urgency or finality, often implying that a task should be completed immediately or a situation should be resolved definitively.
target_language_example: Vamos a terminar esto de una vez.
native_language_example: Let's finish this once and for all.

additional_notes: Used to stress a definitive, final action or decision that will eliminate the issue forever.
target_language_example: Quiero dejar de fumar de una vez para siempre.
native_language_example: I want to quit smoking once and for all.

additional_notes: Used to emphasize ending an issue or task permanently; often conveys urgency or frustration.
target_language_example: Necesito resolver este problema de una vez por todas.
native_language_example: I need to solve this problem once and for all.

meaning: very rarely / once in a blue moon
additional_notes: Informal idiom for events that occur with long gaps between them. Similar to "once in a blue moon" in English. Often used with present tense verbs to describe infrequent habits.
target_language_example: Voy al gimnasio de uvas a peras.
native_language_example: I go to the gym once in a blue moon.

meaning: angry or ready for a fight.
additional_notes: Typically used to describe someone who is upset, aggressive, or defensive, possibly anticipating conflict or an argument.
target_language_example: Después de la discusión, María estaba de uñas todo el día.
native_language_example: After the argument, María was angry all day.

additional_notes: The phrase 'de valor' is used to refer to something valuable, not just in monetary terms but also in terms of significance or usefulness. It often appears when discussing the attributes or quality of objects, ideas, or experiences.
target_language_example: Este libro es de mucho valor para mí.
native_language_example: This book is of great value to me.

additional_notes: Often used to express sincerity or to confirm the truthfulness of something. It can be used in both questions and statements to emphasize genuineness or ask for confirmation.
target_language_example: ¿De verdad crees eso?
native_language_example: Do you really believe that?

additional_notes: This term is used to describe items that are associated with formal or stylish attire, often emphasizing elegance and suitability for special occasions or professional environments.
target_language_example: Necesito comprar zapatos de vestir para la boda.
native_language_example: I need to buy dress shoes for the wedding.

additional_notes: Describes actions or occurrences that happen occasionally, but not on a regular schedule.
target_language_example: Me gusta ir al cine de vez en cuando.
native_language_example: I like to go to the movies from time to time.

additional_notes: Used to describe someone who is not at their usual location because they are traveling.
target_language_example: Mis padres están de viaje.
native_language_example: My parents are on a trip.

additional_notes: Used to describe actions or situations occurring in old age or connected to older people. It can also imply things or habits acquired with age.
target_language_example: Mi abuelo empezó a leer mucho de viejo.
native_language_example: My grandfather started reading a lot when he got old.

meaning: willingly; of one’s own free will.
additional_notes: Often follows verbs like hacer, venir, ayudar, donar, etc., to stress that the person is acting voluntarily. Similar to "voluntariamente" or "por propia voluntad."
target_language_example: Ella decidió quedarse a ayudar de voluntad.
native_language_example: She decided to stay and help of her own free will.

additional_notes: Used to describe the action of returning to a place or state, often in conversation about travel or plans.
target_language_example: Estoy de vuelta en casa.
native_language_example: I am back home.

additional_notes: Used to refer to objects or styles reminiscent of a particular era, often highlighting nostalgic or classic qualities.
target_language_example: Me encanta esa bicicleta de época que tienes.
native_language_example: I love that vintage bike you have.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used in news contexts or when something unexpected happens at the last moment.
target_language_example: Recibimos una noticia de última hora sobre el cambio de horario.
native_language_example: We received a last-minute news update about the schedule change.

additional_notes: Used to describe the position of an object in relation to another object; indicates something being underneath the other.
target_language_example: La pelota está debajo de la mesa.
native_language_example: The ball is under the table.

additional_notes: Used to express obligation, duty, or moral advice. Typically followed by an infinitive (deber + infinitive). Stronger than ‘tener que’ when used without further context.
target_language_example: Debo estudiar para el examen.
native_language_example: I have to study for the exam.

additional_notes: This phrase combines the verb 'deber' (to have to or must) with 'comer' (to eat), indicating an obligation or recommendation. It's often used in advice or expressing necessity.
target_language_example: Debes comer más frutas.
native_language_example: You should eat more fruits.

additional_notes: 'Deber de' is distinct from 'deber' alone, which is used to express obligation or necessity. 'Deber de' is used to indicate that something is probable or likely, rather than certain.
target_language_example: Él debe de estar en casa ahora.
native_language_example: He must be at home now.

additional_notes: Used when making assumptions or educated guesses about a situation or condition. 'Deber de ser' suggests possibility rather than certainty, compared to 'deber ser', which implies obligation or duty.
target_language_example: Ella debe de ser la nueva profesora.
native_language_example: She must be the new teacher.

additional_notes: Used to express obligation or necessity, often indicating the speaker's intent to be honest or forthcoming.
target_language_example: Debería decir la verdad sobre lo que ocurrió.
native_language_example: I should say the truth about what happened.

additional_notes: Commonly used to express that someone has the obligation or necessity to enter a particular place or situation. It is a combination of the auxiliary verb 'deber' (to must) and 'entrar' (to enter).
target_language_example: Debes entrar al edificio antes de las seis.
native_language_example: You must enter the building before six.

additional_notes: This term is often used when expressing a necessity to wait or be patient. It implies that waiting is required or advisable in a certain situation.
target_language_example: Debemos esperar antes de tomar una decisión.
native_language_example: We must wait before making a decision.

additional_notes: Typically used to express that someone should be in a particular state or condition, or is expected to be somewhere. Combines modal verb 'deber' with 'estar', implying an obligation or expectation.
target_language_example: Deber estar en casa a las ocho.
native_language_example: You should be home by eight.

additional_notes: Used when talking about someone being expected or advised to smoke, although the context is often hypothetical or a suggestion as smoking is generally not promoted.
target_language_example: No deberías fumar por tu salud, pero si insistes, deber fumar solo afuera.
native_language_example: You shouldn't smoke for your health, but if you insist, you should smoke only outside.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used in contexts of competition or sports, indicating that winning is necessary or expected.
target_language_example: El equipo debe ganar el partido para avanzar a la final.
native_language_example: The team must win the match to advance to the final.

additional_notes: This is used to express certainty or a strong assumption about something that occurred in the past.
target_language_example: Ella debe haber salido temprano hoy.
native_language_example: She must have left early today.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to indicate a situation or event that was expected to occur but didn't, often reflecting on advice or missed opportunities. It may also be seen in contexts suggesting a reflection on past events.
target_language_example: No debió haber pasado así.
native_language_example: It shouldn't have happened like that.

additional_notes: This phrase is used when someone ought to have a conversation or it is necessary for them to express themselves verbally. It can be used in both formal and informal contexts, depending on the situation.
target_language_example: Deber hablar sobre tus sentimientos con ella.
native_language_example: You should talk about your feelings with her.

additional_notes: Used to express that an action is necessary or required, conveying a sense of duty or obligation.
target_language_example: Tú debes hacer los deberes antes de cenar.
native_language_example: You must do your homework before dinner.

additional_notes: This phrase indicates an obligation or strong suggestion to go somewhere or to do something involving movement. It is often used when giving advice or instructions.
target_language_example: Debo ir al médico mañana.
native_language_example: I must go to the doctor tomorrow.

additional_notes: Used to express obligation or necessity regarding leaving or departing. Can be used conversationally when someone has to exit a situation or location urgently or due to obligations.
target_language_example: Ella debe irse ahora porque tiene una reunión.
native_language_example: She must leave now because she has a meeting.

additional_notes: This phrase can be used in literary or dramatic contexts to discuss fate or necessity of death. Be cautious with its usage due to its strong and potentially negative connotations.
target_language_example: En la historia, el héroe siente que debe morir para salvar a su pueblo.
native_language_example: In the story, the hero feels that he must die to save his people.

additional_notes: This phrase is typically used when discussing plans or obligations to leave or exit a place.
target_language_example: Deberías salir temprano para evitar el tráfico.
native_language_example: You should leave early to avoid traffic.

additional_notes: This phrase is used when expressing an obligation or assumption about what something ought to be like.
target_language_example: El informe debe ser claro y conciso.
native_language_example: The report must be clear and concise.

additional_notes: Used to express obligation or necessity in completing a task or action. Often used in contexts like work, studies, or daily responsibilities.
target_language_example: Tengo que deber terminar mi tarea antes de la cena.
native_language_example: I must finish my homework before dinner.

additional_notes: Used to express a necessity or obligation for someone to arrive or appear at a location. This phrase suggests a level of responsibility or duty.
target_language_example: Tú debes venir a la reunión a tiempo.
native_language_example: You must come to the meeting on time.

additional_notes: Used to recommend viewing something due to its quality or importance. Often used in the context of movies, TV shows, or other visual media.
target_language_example: Es una película que debes ver.
native_language_example: It's a movie you must see.

additional_notes: Used for explaining the cause or reason behind something. It precedes a noun or a noun phrase that indicates the reason.
target_language_example: Cancelaron el vuelo debido al mal tiempo.
native_language_example: The flight was canceled due to bad weather.

additional_notes: Used when parting ways with someone, whether temporarily or permanently. It can be both formal and informal, depending on context.
target_language_example: Es hora de decir adiós a nuestros amigos.
native_language_example: It's time to say goodbye to our friends.

meaning: 'to say like this' or 'to put it this way'.
additional_notes: This phrase is often used when explaining something more clearly or when trying to simplify a statement or idea.
target_language_example: Déjame decirlo así para que lo entiendas.
native_language_example: Let me put it this way so that you understand.

additional_notes: This phrase is used for greeting someone in a casual context. It's common in everyday conversation and can signal friendliness when initiating conversation.
target_language_example: Voy a decir hola cuando llegue.
native_language_example: I am going to say hello when I arrive.

additional_notes: Used to express that someone is speaking truthfully or being honest in what they're saying.
target_language_example: Él siempre trata de decir la verdad.
native_language_example: He always tries to tell the truth.

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used when confirming or repeating information, or expressing agreement with someone else's statement.
target_language_example: Ella siempre dice lo mismo cuando le preguntan sobre su película favorita.
native_language_example: She always says the same thing when asked about her favorite movie.

additional_notes: Commonly used when declining an invitation, offer, or proposal. It is a versatile phrase applicable in many informal and formal situations.
target_language_example: No me gusta tener que decir que no a la invitación.
native_language_example: I don't like having to say no to the invitation.

additional_notes: Literally translates to 'finger of the foot'. Used to refer to an individual toe on the foot.
target_language_example: Me duele el dedo del pie.
native_language_example: My toe hurts.

additional_notes: This term is often used in the context of personal safety measures or techniques to protect oneself, such as martial arts or self-defense classes.
target_language_example: Estoy tomando clases de defensa personal para sentirme más segura.
native_language_example: I am taking self-defense classes to feel safer.

additional_notes: Commonly used for (1) leaving something or someone in a place, (2) allowing or permitting someone to do something, and (3) stopping an action when followed by "de" + infinitive (e.g., dejar de fumar = to quit smoking).
target_language_example: ¿Me dejas usar tu teléfono?
native_language_example: Will you let me use your phone?

additional_notes: Used not only for physically dropping objects but also for subtly making a suggestion or revealing information.
target_language_example: Ella dejó caer el vaso por accidente.
native_language_example: She dropped the glass by accident.

additional_notes: Always followed by an infinitive verb. Used to say someone no longer does an action.
target_language_example: Dejé de fumar el año pasado.
native_language_example: I stopped smoking last year.

additional_notes: The expression can be used when discussing permission to speak or express an opinion. It's not commonly used in everyday conversation but may appear in certain contexts where permission to speak is discussed.
target_language_example: El profesor dejó decir a los estudiantes sus opiniones.
native_language_example: The teacher allowed the students to say their opinions.

meaning: to leave alone or leave in peace.
additional_notes: It is often used when you wish someone to stop bothering you or someone else, either physically or verbally.
target_language_example: Déjame en paz, estoy ocupado.
native_language_example: Leave me alone, I'm busy.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used in contexts where permission is needed for someone to enter a place or join an activity. It's a combination of the verb "dejar" (to let/allow) and "entrar" (to enter).
target_language_example: ¿Puedes dejar entrar al perro, por favor?
native_language_example: Can you let the dog in, please?

additional_notes: Used when deliberately allowing another person to win, often to encourage them or as a gesture of kindness.
target_language_example: A veces dejo ganar a mis hermanos pequeños al ajedrez.
native_language_example: Sometimes I let my younger siblings win at chess.

additional_notes: Often used in contexts of emotional release or moving on from past events or relationships.
target_language_example: Es difícil dejar ir las cosas que amas.
native_language_example: It is difficult to let go of the things you love.

additional_notes: This phrase can be used literally when talking about living beings, or metaphorically in contexts like letting a plant die by not watering it or letting a project or relationship cease without intervention.
target_language_example: No puedes dejar morir esa planta sin intentarlo.
native_language_example: You can't let that plant die without trying.

additional_notes: Can be used literally, such as allowing someone or something to physically pass through a space, or figuratively, such as overlooking an action or not taking advantage of an opportunity.
target_language_example: No podemos dejar pasar esta oportunidad.
native_language_example: We cannot let this opportunity pass by.

additional_notes: Used when someone fails to show up for a scheduled meeting or social engagement, leaving the other person waiting and usually feeling abandoned or disappointed.
target_language_example: Me dejó plantado en el restaurante.
native_language_example: He stood me up at the restaurant.

meaning: to let finish or to allow to finish.
additional_notes: It's commonly used in situations where one person is asking another for the patience or permission to complete an action or sentence. It can be used both in literal senses (like letting someone finish a task) and in more abstract or conversational contexts (like allowing someone to finish their point in a discussion).
target_language_example: Por favor, déjame terminar mi trabajo antes de irnos.
native_language_example: Please let me finish my work before we leave.

meaning: to let see or allow to see
additional_notes: This phrase implies permission to view or check something. It can be used literally for physically seeing something or figuratively for allowing someone to understand or realize something.
target_language_example: Ella me dejó ver su nuevo libro.
native_language_example: She let me see her new book.

additional_notes: Used to describe something deeply connected to one's emotions or essence. Commonly used in poetic or expressive contexts, it can refer to a cherished aspect of a person's character or deep feelings.
target_language_example: Ella canta con una voz del alma.
native_language_example: She sings with a soulful voice.

meaning: 'of the devil', often used for emphasis.
additional_notes: Used to intensify the sentiment, usually to describe something troublesome or annoying. Similar to using 'damn' or 'devilish' in English to express frustration or intensity.
target_language_example: Este tráfico del demonio me hace llegar tarde.
native_language_example: This damn traffic is making me late.

additional_notes: Refers back to a previously mentioned masculine singular noun (autor, tipo, lugar, etc.). Functions like “of/from the same (one)”. For feminine or plural forms use "de la misma", "de los mismos", "de las mismas".
target_language_example: Compré dos libros del mismo autor.
native_language_example: I bought two books by the same author.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe something with global significance, rank, or origin. For instance, in titles of contests (e.g., 'la mejor pizza del mundo'), it indicates a worldwide scale or comparison.
target_language_example: Es el mejor chef del mundo.
native_language_example: He is the best chef in the world.

additional_notes: Can be used to describe physical locations as well as metaphorical concepts, such as opinions or perspectives.
target_language_example: La tienda está del otro lado de la calle.
native_language_example: The store is on the other side of the street.

additional_notes: Highlights that something is done, covered, or experienced completely, without skipping any part.
target_language_example: Vi la película del principio al fin.
native_language_example: I watched the movie from beginning to end.

meaning: used to describe something very extreme or noteworthy.
additional_notes: This phrase is often used in informal contexts to emphasize the intensity or extent of a characteristic, similar to how one might say "of the century" or "incredible" in English.
target_language_example: La fiesta fue un desastre del quince.
native_language_example: The party was an incredible disaster.

additional_notes: It is often used in contexts like describing the weather, drinks, or events typical of a season or a general reference to 'room temperature'.
target_language_example: Me gusta el vino del tiempo, no frío.
native_language_example: I like wine at room temperature, not cold.

additional_notes: Often appears with a negative or in questions: "no está del todo claro" (it isn’t completely clear). Can also be used affirmatively but that is less frequent.
target_language_example: No entiendo del todo la explicación.
native_language_example: I don't completely understand the explanation.

del árbol caído todos hacen leña

target_language_multi_word_term: del árbol caído todos hacen leña
additional_notes: This phrase carries a moral lesson about the opportunistic behavior people may display when they see someone else failing or in a bad situation. It suggests a critique of taking advantage of others' weaknesses.
target_language_example: Después de su despido, muchos colegas comenzaron a hablar mal de él. Del árbol caído todos hacen leña.
native_language_example: After his dismissal, many colleagues started speaking badly about him. People exploit others' misfortunes.

additional_notes: This phrase is typically used to describe spatial position. It can refer to physical locations as well as more abstract concepts, such as standing in front of a group figuratively.
target_language_example: El coche está delante de la casa.
native_language_example: The car is in front of the house.

additional_notes: Used to describe something located inside a physical space or to specify a time frame, e.g., 'within two hours'.
target_language_example: El gato está dentro de la caja.
native_language_example: The cat is inside the box.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to indicate reliance or that something is contingent upon something else. It requires the preposition 'de' to connect to whatever is being depended on.
target_language_example: Todo depende de la decisión del jefe.
native_language_example: Everything depends on the boss's decision.

additional_notes: Refers to legal matters concerning private citizens and their rights. It is distinguished from criminal law which deals with offenses against the state or public.
target_language_example: El contrato fue redactado de acuerdo con el derecho civil.
native_language_example: The contract was drafted in accordance with civil law.

additional_notes: Refers to the fundamental rights and freedoms that all individuals are entitled to regardless of nationality, gender, ethnicity, religion, or any other status.
target_language_example: El derecho humano a la educación debe ser garantizado para todos.
native_language_example: The human right to education must be guaranteed for everyone.

additional_notes: Used to express condolences or a wish for someone who has died to have peace in the afterlife. It is often abbreviated as 'RIP' in English.
target_language_example: Espero que descanse en paz.
native_language_example: I hope he rests in peace.

additional_notes: Used as a traditional expression of sympathy for someone who has passed away, often abbreviated as 'DEP' on gravestones and memorials.
target_language_example: Siempre recordaremos a nuestra abuela. Descanse en paz.
native_language_example: We will always remember our grandmother. Rest in peace.

additional_notes: This phrase is used when describing starting something new or beginning again without any prior progress or resources.
target_language_example: Aprendí a cocinar desde cero.
native_language_example: I learned to cook from scratch.

desde el vientre de su madre

target_language_multi_word_term: desde el vientre de su madre
meaning: from his/her mother’s womb; since birth
additional_notes: Highlights that something has been true from the very beginning of a person’s life, often used figuratively to stress lifelong traits or experiences.
target_language_example: Él ama la música desde el vientre de su madre.
native_language_example: He has loved music since before he was born.

additional_notes: Used to express continuity of action or state from a past point in time to the present or another reference point.
target_language_example: Empezó a estudiar mucho más y, desde entonces, sus notas han mejorado.
native_language_example: He started studying much more and, since then, his grades have improved.

additional_notes: Used to describe an action or situation that started in the past and continues into the present.
target_language_example: Vivo aquí desde hace dos años.
native_language_example: I have lived here for two years.

additional_notes: Used to describe something that has been happening or has existed for a significant amount of time.
target_language_example: Estoy estudiando español desde hace mucho.
native_language_example: I have been studying Spanish for a long time.

additional_notes: Used to confirm or agree with something that has been said, implying that the answer is obvious or expected.
target_language_example: ¿Vendrás a la fiesta esta noche? - Desde luego.
native_language_example: Will you come to the party tonight? - Of course.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to link an action or state to a specific starting point in the past. It can indicate both time and causation within context.
target_language_example: Ha sido mucho más feliz desde que terminó la escuela.
native_language_example: She's been much happier since she finished school.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that something happened, was decided, or remained consistent from the start of a period or situation.
target_language_example: Desde un principio, supimos que sería difícil.
native_language_example: From the beginning, we knew it would be difficult.

additional_notes: Preposition used before a noun, pronoun, or infinitive to say that one action/event happens later than another. Combine with the article "el" as "después del" (e.g., después del trabajo).
target_language_example: Vamos al cine después de cenar.
native_language_example: We’re going to the movies after having dinner.

additional_notes: Used to connect two clauses, with the first action occurring before the action in the main clause. Often requires the subjunctive mood when there's uncertainty or a future context.
target_language_example: Nos vemos después de que termine la reunión.
native_language_example: We'll see each other after the meeting ends.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to introduce a conclusive statement or to justify a previous one after considering all facts or circumstances.
target_language_example: Decidí no salir, después de todo, estoy muy cansado.
native_language_example: I decided not to go out, after all, I'm very tired.

additional_notes: Used to refer to someone who investigates matters privately, often for hire, rather than as part of a police organization.
target_language_example: El detective privado fue contratado para investigar el caso.
native_language_example: The private detective was hired to investigate the case.

additional_notes: Used to describe the location of an object relative to another, indicating that it is at the back of or in a rear position.
target_language_example: El perro está detrás de la casa.
native_language_example: The dog is behind the house.

additional_notes: Used to refer to the location of someone or something in relation to a door.
target_language_example: El perro está durmiendo detrás de la puerta.
native_language_example: The dog is sleeping behind the door.

additional_notes: Used when a task is accomplished immediately after it is mentioned, emphasizing the quick follow-through on a suggestion or command.
target_language_example: Le pedí que arreglara el coche y, dicho y hecho, al día siguiente ya estaba arreglado.
native_language_example: I asked him to fix the car and, no sooner said than done, it was fixed the next day.

additional_notes: Used to describe a large number or quantity. Formed by combining "diez" (ten) and "mil" (thousand). Common in daily conversations involving money, population statistics, distances, etc.
target_language_example: El estadio tiene capacidad para diez mil personas.
native_language_example: The stadium has a capacity for ten thousand people.

additional_notes: Used at the end of a sentence to express personal opinion or to propose an assumption, often to lessen the force of a statement and invite agreement.
target_language_example: Eso es una tontería, digo yo.
native_language_example: That's nonsense, I say.

additional_notes: This term is often used in discussions about tax evasion, corruption, and illicit financial activities.
target_language_example: El político fue acusado de tener dinero negro en su cuenta.
native_language_example: The politician was accused of having black money in his account.

additional_notes: Used when referring to someone's email contact information. Essential in modern communication, especially in written forms or when filling out forms online.
target_language_example: Por favor, envíame tu dirección de correo electrónico.
native_language_example: Please send me your email address.

additional_notes: Used to refer to the part of a computer where data is stored for long-term. It is a commonly used term in technology and computer-related contexts.
target_language_example: Necesito más espacio en mi disco duro.
native_language_example: I need more space on my hard drive.

additional_notes: A common term in discussions about the environment, climate change, and respiration.
target_language_example: Las plantas absorben dióxido de carbono y liberan oxígeno.
native_language_example: Plants absorb carbon dioxide and release oxygen.

additional_notes: Commonly used when giving or following directions. It involves changing direction when reaching the corner of a street or road.
target_language_example: Al llegar al parque, debes doblar la esquina a la derecha.
native_language_example: When you reach the park, you should turn the corner to the right.

additional_notes: It literally translates to 'pain of head', a straightforward way to describe a headache. Often used in expressions of discomfort or when explaining an ailment.
target_language_example: Tengo un dolor de cabeza muy fuerte.
native_language_example: I have a very bad headache.

additional_notes: This phrase is typically used to describe someone who is considered insignificant or who has little social influence.
target_language_example: Él siempre ha sido un don nadie en esa compañía.
native_language_example: He has always been a nobody in that company.

additional_notes: The phrase is not commonly used alone in Spanish. It might be found in literary or poetic contexts rather than in everyday conversation. Typically, 'donde' and 'querer' are used separately, for example, 'donde quieras' meaning 'where you want.'
target_language_example: Ella busca siempre donde querer ir en sus aventuras.
native_language_example: She always looks for where to want to go on her adventures.

additional_notes: Used when the speaker is indifferent to the choice of location, accepting any possibility or location presented.
target_language_example: Podemos ir a cenar donde sea.
native_language_example: We can go to dinner anywhere.

additional_notes: Standard, polite way to order in a bar or restaurant. Replace the number or item to order other quantities or drinks.
target_language_example: Dos cervezas, por favor, y una tapa de patatas bravas.
native_language_example: Two beers, please, and a serving of patatas bravas.

additional_notes: In addition to being a numerical figure, 'dos mil' can be used in historical or future contexts to refer to the year. Spanish numbers follow a decimal system similar to English.
target_language_example: En el año dos mil, visitamos Europa.
native_language_example: In the year two thousand, we visited Europe.

additional_notes: Used to indicate an uncertain or approximate number, often when the exact quantity is not necessary to be specified.
target_language_example: Necesito dos o tres manzanas para la receta.
native_language_example: I need two or three apples for the recipe.

additional_notes: This phrase indicates an approximate frequency. It is often used when the exact number of times something happened is not crucial or the speaker is estimating.
target_language_example: Visité México dos o tres veces el año pasado.
native_language_example: I visited Mexico two or three times last year.

additional_notes: Used to introduce an explanation, list, or quotation, similar to its use in English writing.
target_language_example: Necesitas estos ingredientes para la receta: harina, huevos, y leche.
native_language_example: You need these ingredients for the recipe: flour, eggs, and milk.

additional_notes: This is used to indicate an action or event occurring the same way two times.
target_language_example: Fui al cine dos veces esta semana.
native_language_example: I went to the cinema twice this week.

additional_notes: Used as a way to wish someone a peaceful night's rest; often used with friends or loved ones before they go to sleep.
target_language_example: Buenas noches, que tengas dulces sueños.
native_language_example: Good night, may you have sweet dreams.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that something occurs or continues over a lengthy period. Common in past tense narratives but can be used in present or future contexts.
target_language_example: Vivió en España durante mucho tiempo.
native_language_example: He lived in Spain for a long time.

additional_notes: This phrase is generally used to describe someone who is pretending to have qualities or skills they do not possess. It often conveys a negative connotation, suggesting that the person is boasting or trying to impress others with false claims.
target_language_example: Él siempre se las da de experto, pero no sabe mucho del tema.
native_language_example: He always pretends to be an expert, but he doesn't know much about the subject.

additional_notes: Used to describe regular, daily actions or incremental progress. It can refer to routines, habits, or continuous effort in daily life or work.
target_language_example: Trabajo para mejorar mi español día a día.
native_language_example: I work to improve my Spanish day by day.

additional_notes: Refers to a day when there is no work or school due to a holiday or celebration. Can be used for national holidays or personal days off.
target_language_example: El lunes es un día festivo, así que no tenemos que ir al trabajo.
native_language_example: Monday is a holiday, so we don't have to go to work.

additional_notes: Used to express something that happens repeatedly or continuously over time.
target_language_example: Él va al gimnasio día tras día.
native_language_example: He goes to the gym day after day.

additional_notes: Can be used to describe something that happens continuously or all the time. Often used for emphasis and to indicate persistence or thoroughness.
target_language_example: Estudia día y noche para el examen.
native_language_example: He studies day and night for the exam.

additional_notes: Commonly used to indicate a passage of time between two events.
target_language_example: Nos encontramos días después del concierto.
native_language_example: We met days after the concert.

additional_notes: This phrase is typically used to inquire about the location of a specific person or object.
target_language_example: ¿Dónde está el baño?
native_language_example: Where is the bathroom?

additional_notes: Used to inquire about the location of a person. Often followed by further questions or information to arrange a meeting or understand a situation.
target_language_example: ¿Dónde estás, Pedro?
native_language_example: Where are you, Pedro?

additional_notes: Used when someone starts running suddenly, often due to fear, excitement, or urgency.
target_language_example: Cuando vio al perro, echó a correr.
native_language_example: When he saw the dog, he started running.

additional_notes: This phrase can be used in various contexts, such as when referring to spoiled food, a ruined plan, or a damaged object.
target_language_example: La lluvia echó a perder el picnic.
native_language_example: The rain spoiled the picnic.

additional_notes: A frequently used expression to convey longing or a feeling of missing someone or something when they're not around. It is informal and used in conversational contexts.
target_language_example: Echo de menos a mi familia.
native_language_example: I miss my family.

meaning: 'to blame' or 'to put the blame on'.
additional_notes: Used to indicate that someone is assigning blame or responsibility to someone else for something negative that has happened.
target_language_example: Siempre me echan la culpa cuando algo sale mal.
native_language_example: They always blame me when something goes wrong.

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used in informal contexts when you want to quickly examine something without a detailed observation. It's the equivalent of 'taking a peek' or 'having a quick look' in English.
target_language_example: Voy a echar un vistazo al informe antes de la reunión.
native_language_example: I'm going to take a look at the report before the meeting.

meaning: to lend a hand; to help.
additional_notes: This phrase is used to signify providing help or assistance to someone in need. It is commonly applied in situations where physical help is required but can also be used more generally for offering support or aid in tasks or projects.
target_language_example: ¿Puedes echarme una mano con estas cajas?
native_language_example: Can you lend me a hand with these boxes?

additional_notes: Occurs when the Earth is positioned directly between the Sun and the Moon, casting a shadow on the Moon. It's a common term in both astronomy and everyday discussions about lunar phases or viewing events.
target_language_example: Durante un eclipse lunar, la luna se ve roja.
native_language_example: During a lunar eclipse, the moon looks red.

additional_notes: This term is used to describe classes at school focused on physical exercise, sports, and promoting fitness. In many educational systems, 'educación física' is an essential part of the curriculum.
target_language_example: Mañana tenemos clase de educación física.
native_language_example: Tomorrow we have physical education class.

additional_notes: Commonly used in medical contexts to refer to unintended reactions to medications or treatments. It's important to understand when discussing health-related topics.
target_language_example: Este medicamento puede causar un efecto secundario.
native_language_example: This medication can cause a side effect.

additional_notes: This phrase expresses the idea that people don't see the imperfections of those they love.
target_language_example: Dicen que el amor es ciego.
native_language_example: They say that love is blind.

additional_notes: Used as a relative pronoun to introduce subordinate clauses, often following a comma and referring back to a specific noun that has been mentioned earlier. Formal in register.
target_language_example: El libro, el cual compré ayer, es muy interesante.
native_language_example: The book, which I bought yesterday, is very interesting.

additional_notes: Commonly used in both speaking and writing to refer to today, often adding formality or clarity to when something is happening.
target_language_example: Hoy tenemos una reunión importante el día de hoy.
native_language_example: Today we have an important meeting today.

additional_notes: Used to refer to someone chosen for a special purpose or task, often implying destiny or selection by a higher power.
target_language_example: Él es el elegido para liderar nuestra misión.
native_language_example: He is the chosen one to lead our mission.

additional_notes: Used to indicate ownership or something that belongs to the speaker. It corresponds to a masculine singular noun previously mentioned in the conversation or context.
target_language_example: El libro es el mío.
native_language_example: The book is mine.

additional_notes: Used to talk about an unspecified recent day in the past. It implies some event or action happened not too long ago but does not indicate a specific day.
target_language_example: Vi a María el otro día en el supermercado.
native_language_example: I saw María the other day at the supermarket.

additional_notes: Used to single out a specific person or thing previously mentioned or implied. It agrees in gender/number (el que, la que, los que, las que). Frequently introduces relative clauses.
target_language_example: El que llegue primero gana.
native_language_example: The one who arrives first wins.

additional_notes: Used to express that any choice or option is acceptable. Commonly used in casual or informal conversations when the specific choice doesn't matter much.
target_language_example: Podemos ir a cualquier restaurante, el que sea está bien para mí.
native_language_example: We can go to any restaurant, whichever is fine with me.

additional_notes: Used to convey that the results or consequences of an event will become clear in the future. It's often used when the outcome is uncertain or when patience is needed.
target_language_example: No sabemos si este proyecto tendrá éxito, el tiempo dirá.
native_language_example: We don't know if this project will be successful, time will tell.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to express surprise or acknowledgment at how quickly time seems to be passing, often in the context of reflecting on a past period.
target_language_example: Parece que empezamos ayer, pero ya han pasado diez años. ¡El tiempo vuela!
native_language_example: It seems like we started yesterday, but ten years have already passed. Time flies!

additional_notes: It is used to indicate a mutual action or relationship between two or more people or things, often involving reciprocal verbs. The phrase will vary slightly depending on gender and number (e.g., la una a la otra for feminine).
target_language_example: Ellos se ayudan el uno al otro.
native_language_example: They help each other.

meaning: under the table; off the books.
additional_notes: Refers to payments or money that are not reported to the tax office, often in cash, to avoid taxes. Common collocations: "pagar en B", "cobrar en B", "dinero en B".
target_language_example: Me pagaron en B para evitar impuestos.
native_language_example: They paid me under the table to avoid taxes.

additional_notes: Traditional proverb commenting on frequent spring rain in Spain and Latin America; often used to remind someone to expect wet weather or carry an umbrella.
