additional_notes: Used to wish someone joy and happiness during the Christmas holiday season. It is comparable to the English 'Merry Christmas.' The phrase is popular in both Spanish-speaking countries and international contexts.
target_language_example: Te deseo una feliz Navidad y un próspero Año Nuevo.
native_language_example: I wish you a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year.

additional_notes: Mainly used around the New Year to wish someone well for the year ahead. Most commonly seen in the phrase 'Feliz Año Nuevo'.
target_language_example: Te deseo un feliz año.
native_language_example: I wish you a happy year.

additional_notes: This expression is used to convey good wishes for the upcoming year. It's commonly heard during New Year's Eve and the first days of January. It's a standard greeting exchanged among friends, family, and sometimes even strangers when welcoming the new year.
target_language_example: Te deseo un feliz año nuevo lleno de alegrías.
native_language_example: I wish you a happy new year full of joy.

additional_notes: Used to congratulate someone on the anniversary of their birth. Typically used in informal or friendly interactions.
target_language_example: ¡Feliz cumpleaños, Ana! Espero que tengas un día maravilloso.
native_language_example: Happy birthday, Ana! I hope you have a wonderful day.

additional_notes: In Spanish-speaking cultures, 'fiesta de cumpleaños' is a festive event where family and friends gather to celebrate the birthday of an individual, often involving food, drinks, music, and sometimes special customs such as breaking a piñata.
target_language_example: Vamos a tener una fiesta de cumpleaños para María este sábado.
native_language_example: We are going to have a birthday party for Maria this Saturday.

additional_notes: Used to refer to Saturday and Sunday collectively, or the period from Friday evening to Sunday night when people typically have time off work or school.
target_language_example: ¿Tienes algún plan para el fin de semana?
native_language_example: Do you have any plans for the weekend?

additional_notes: Used metaphorically to describe a very distant place or an extreme situation, not just the literal apocalypse.
target_language_example: Vivimos en un pequeño pueblo en el fin del mundo.
native_language_example: We live in a small town at the end of the world.

additional_notes: Used to describe stories or situations that conclude positively or happily. Can be used in both literal and figurative contexts.
target_language_example: La película tuvo un final feliz.
native_language_example: The movie had a happy ending.

additional_notes: Often associated with the beauty of nature, springtime, and the fleeting nature of life. "Flor de cerezo" can also be used in artistic contexts such as paintings and poetry.
target_language_example: Las flores de cerezo en primavera son un espectáculo hermoso.
native_language_example: The cherry blossoms in spring are a beautiful sight.

additional_notes: Used to describe someone's particular style of speech, including their choice of words, tone, and accent.
target_language_example: Su forma de hablar es muy elegante.
native_language_example: Her way of speaking is very elegant.

additional_notes: This phrase is generally used to describe how someone lives, including their habits, routines, and cultural practices. It encapsulates one's overall approach to life including health, work, leisure, and social relationships.
target_language_example: Ella decidió cambiar su forma de vida y ahora come más saludable.
native_language_example: She decided to change her way of life and now eats healthier.

additional_notes: Commonly used when someone is included in a group, organization, or an activity. It indicates belonging or participation.
target_language_example: Ella quiere formar parte del equipo de fútbol.
native_language_example: She wants to be part of the soccer team.

additional_notes: Used to describe position, opposition, or comparison between two things. Can also indicate a confrontational stance or approach.
target_language_example: El banco está frente a la iglesia.
native_language_example: The bank is in front of the church.

additional_notes: Commonly used to express that someone is eagerly awaiting or excited about a future event or outcome, especially when expecting it to lead to personal gain or success.
target_language_example: Él se frota las manos mientras espera que lleguen las buenas noticias.
native_language_example: He rubs his hands together as he waits for the good news to arrive.

meaning: to frown or furrow one's brow.
additional_notes: This phrase is often used to describe someone's facial expression when they are upset or deep in thought, and it is quite similar to the English expression 'furrow the brows'.
target_language_example: Cuando leí el informe, no pude evitar fruncir el ceño por la sorpresa.
native_language_example: When I read the report, I couldn't help but frown in surprise.

additional_notes: In Spanish, 'fruto seco' refers to nuts like almonds and walnuts, and some dried fruits that naturally have little water content, like raisins.
target_language_example: Me encanta comer frutos secos como almendras y nueces.
native_language_example: I love eating nuts like almonds and walnuts.

additional_notes: Used to describe the colorful explosives displayed in the sky during celebrations like New Year's Eve or the 4th of July in the US.
target_language_example: El espectáculo de fuego artificial fue impresionante.
native_language_example: The fireworks display was impressive.

additional_notes: Used to indicate physical location or metaphorical contexts, such as being outside of a certain circle or beyond expectations.
target_language_example: El gato está fuera de la casa.
native_language_example: The cat is outside of the house.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to describe situations that are not manageable or under control. It's often used to talk about situations that have escalated beyond normal bounds, such as emergencies, riots, or any scenario where there's a lack of order.
target_language_example: El incendio forestal está fuera de control.
native_language_example: The wildfire is out of control.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe behavior or comments that are not suitable for the situation. It can also refer to something that is physically out of its correct location.
target_language_example: Su comentario fue completamente fuera de lugar durante la reunión.
native_language_example: His comment was completely out of place during the meeting.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe devices, vehicles, or facilities that are temporarily not working or are under maintenance.
target_language_example: El ascensor está fuera de servicio.
native_language_example: The elevator is out of order.

additional_notes: This term refers to the military branch responsible for aerial warfare and operations. It is used in contexts related to defense, military and aviation.
target_language_example: La fuerza aérea realizó un ejercicio militar esta semana.
native_language_example: The air force conducted a military exercise this week.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to describe someone's personal strength in overcoming difficulties or persevering through challenges or temptations.
target_language_example: Ella tiene mucha fuerza de voluntad para dejar de fumar.
native_language_example: She has a lot of willpower to quit smoking.

additional_notes: 'Fútbol americano' is used to specifically refer to the sport of American football, distinguishing it from soccer, which is called 'fútbol' in Spanish.
target_language_example: Me gusta jugar al fútbol americano los domingos.
native_language_example: I like to play American football on Sundays.

additional_notes: Used to describe protective eyewear worn to shield the eyes from sunlight, often associated with outdoor activities and as a fashion accessory.
target_language_example: Necesito comprar unas gafas de sol para el verano.
native_language_example: I need to buy some sunglasses for the summer.

additional_notes: A 'galería de arte' is typically a space where artworks are exhibited and sometimes sold. It's a common term used in cities known for their art scenes.
target_language_example: Visitamos la galería de arte durante nuestra estancia en Madrid.
native_language_example: We visited the art gallery during our stay in Madrid.

meaning: to save time or gain time.
additional_notes: Used when referring to actions that help to save or make better use of time, like finding efficiencies or shortcuts.
target_language_example: Necesitamos una estrategia para ganar tiempo y terminar el proyecto antes.
native_language_example: We need a strategy to save time and finish the project early.

additional_notes: This phrase refers to the act of working to make money necessary for daily expenses and supporting one's lifestyle.
target_language_example: Él trabaja duro para ganarse la vida.
native_language_example: He works hard to earn a living.

additional_notes: Used to describe a specific breed of cat known for its luxurious fur and distinctive appearance. Gender can change to 'gato persa' for a male Persian cat.
target_language_example: Mi vecina tiene una gata persa muy bonita.
native_language_example: My neighbor has a very beautiful Persian cat.

additional_notes: This term is used to describe a specific cat breed known for its long fur and calm demeanor. 'Gato' means cat, and 'persa' refers to Persian, indicating the breed's origins. This breed is often associated with luxury and pedigree.
target_language_example: Mi hermana tiene un gato persa.
native_language_example: My sister has a Persian cat.

additional_notes: Used to specify that a twin has the same appearance as their sibling due to being monozygotic.
target_language_example: Ella siempre confunde a mi gemela idéntica y a mí.
native_language_example: She always confuses my identical twin and me.

additional_notes: This term is used to describe a type of twin who shares the exact same genetic makeup as their sibling. It's often used in the context of family, genetics, or when discussing similarities between siblings.
target_language_example: Sara y Lara son gemelas idénticas, nadie puede diferenciarlas.
native_language_example: Sara and Lara are identical twins, no one can tell them apart.

additional_notes: It is used to indicate that something positive or a favorable outcome occurred because of someone else's actions or presence. It can also be used more broadly to refer to any cause of an outcome, positive or negative.
target_language_example: Llegamos a tiempo gracias a que salió el sol temprano.
native_language_example: We arrived on time thanks to the fact that the sun rose early.

additional_notes: Used to express relief or gratitude, often when something has resolved in a positive way.
target_language_example: Gracias a Dios, nadie resultó herido en el accidente.
native_language_example: Thank God, no one was injured in the accident.

additional_notes: Used to describe a large retail establishment with various departments offering different types of products.
target_language_example: Vamos al gran almacén para comprar ropa.
native_language_example: Let's go to the department store to buy clothes.

additional_notes: Often used in contexts where someone is downplaying or questioning the importance of something, similar to the English phrase 'it's no big deal'.
target_language_example: No te preocupes por eso, no es gran cosa.
native_language_example: Don't worry about it, it's no big deal.

additional_notes: This term is used to encourage or acknowledge contributions, no matter how small, to a collective task or purpose. It highlights the importance of individual efforts in achieving a larger goal.
target_language_example: Cada uno debe poner su grano de arena para cuidar el medio ambiente.
native_language_example: Everyone should make their small contribution to take care of the environment.

additional_notes: Describes the language spoken in Greece and the surrounding regions thousands of years ago, known for its significance in classical literature and history.
target_language_example: Estudia griego antiguo para entender mejor los textos clásicos.
native_language_example: He studies Ancient Greek to better understand classical texts.

additional_notes: Used to specify the contemporary variant of the Greek language, distinguishing it from Classical Greek or Koine Greek, which are older forms.
target_language_example: Estoy estudiando griego moderno en la universidad.
native_language_example: I am studying modern Greek at the university.

additional_notes: A 'guardia de seguridad' is usually employed in public or private places to maintain security and safety. This term can be encountered at various venues like malls, banks, and events, where safety and order are required.
target_language_example: El guardia de seguridad vigila la entrada del edificio.
native_language_example: The security guard watches over the entrance of the building.

additional_notes: Used to refer to internal conflicts within a country, typically involving different groups vying for control or opposing governmental policies.
target_language_example: La guerra civil causó mucho sufrimiento en el país.
native_language_example: The civil war caused a lot of suffering in the country.

additional_notes: Refers to a conflict characterized by the use of nuclear weapons between nations or groups. Commonly used in discussions on international security or historical contexts.
target_language_example: Existe un miedo constante de una guerra nuclear.
native_language_example: There is a constant fear of nuclear war.

additional_notes: This term is used to describe a guitar that needs an amplifier to project sound and is commonly used in various music genres such as rock, jazz, and blues.
target_language_example: Él toca la guitarra eléctrica en la banda.
native_language_example: He plays the electric guitar in the band.

additional_notes: Used with indirect object pronouns (me, te, le, nos, os, les). The verb agrees with the thing liked: gusta for singular actions/things, gustan for plural things.
target_language_example: Me gustan los gatos.
native_language_example: I like cats.

meaning: to have (auxiliary) / there is, there are
additional_notes: Used chiefly as an auxiliary to build perfect tenses (he comido = I have eaten). In its impersonal forms (hay, hubo, habrá, etc.) it means 'there is/are' to state existence.
target_language_example: Hay mucha gente y he llegado tarde.
native_language_example: There are many people and I have arrived late.

additional_notes: Used when passing on information that is hearsay or a rumor, without attributing it to a specific source.
target_language_example: Hay que estar atentos, porque hay decir que habrá tormenta esta noche.
native_language_example: We should be cautious, because it is said that there will be a storm tonight.

additional_notes: Perfect infinitive combining "haber" + past participle of "estar". Used after other verbs or prepositions to talk about a completed past state or location.
target_language_example: Me alegra haber estado contigo.
native_language_example: I'm glad to have been with you.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to describe an action that started in the past and continued for some time. It involves the use of auxiliary 'haber' (to have), past participle 'estado' (been), and the gerund 'esperando' (waiting).
target_language_example: He estado esperando durante una hora.
native_language_example: I have been waiting for an hour.

additional_notes: Use haber (usually as “hay”) to say something exists: “there is/are…”. Use estar to say where something is or its state: “is/are (located)”. Do not use estar after hay.
target_language_example: Hay un libro en la mesa, pero el cuaderno está en la mochila.
native_language_example: There is a book on the table, but the notebook is in the backpack.

additional_notes: Perfect infinitive: signals an action finished before another one. Often used after prepositions (después de, antes de, por) or to explain cause/condition.
target_language_example: Después de haber hecho la tarea, salí a jugar.
native_language_example: After having done the homework, I went out to play.

additional_notes: Used in perfect tenses to express the completion of the action 'to arrive'. It is often encountered when speaking about past actions that have relevance in the present or are part of a completed chain of events.
target_language_example: Ella parece cansada de haber llegado tarde.
native_language_example: She seems tired from having arrived late.

additional_notes: Used to express that someone has heard something or about someone in the past. It's an example of forming the perfect tense using 'haber' and a past participle.
target_language_example: He oído que habrá una fiesta este viernes.
native_language_example: I have heard that there will be a party this Friday.

additional_notes: It is often used to discuss whether one has free time for an activity or meeting. Often found in questions or conditional sentences.
target_language_example: ¿Tienes tiempo mañana para un café?
native_language_example: Do you have time tomorrow for a coffee?

additional_notes: This phrase is often used in literary Spanish to imply that someone or something will soon arrive or is about to happen.
target_language_example: Ella habrá de venir mañana para resolver el problema.
native_language_example: She will have to come tomorrow to solve the problem.

additional_notes: Perfect infinitive expressing an action finished prior to another; often used with prepositions or modal verbs (e.g., después de, debería, podría).
target_language_example: Después de haber visto la película, hablamos sobre ella.
native_language_example: After having seen the movie, we talked about it.

meaning: "Do you speak English?" or "(He/She/You) speak(s) English."
additional_notes: It can be used as a question to inquire if someone can communicate in English, but it could also function as a statement indicating someone's ability to speak English. The subject is implied and depends on context, such as 'tú' (you) for informal, 'usted' (you formal), or third person (he/she).
target_language_example: ¿Habla inglés, señor?
native_language_example: Do you speak English, sir?

additional_notes: The term is gender-specific and refers to female native speakers. The masculine form would be 'hablante nativo.'
target_language_example: Ella es una hablante nativa de español.
native_language_example: She is a native Spanish speaker.

additional_notes: Used to describe someone who has spoken a language since early childhood as their primary language.
target_language_example: Ella es una hablante nativa de español.
native_language_example: She is a native speaker of Spanish.

additional_notes: Use it before the person you want to address (a name, pronoun, or noun). Often appears when arranging conversations or asking to speak to someone.
target_language_example: Quiero hablar con María esta tarde.
native_language_example: I want to talk with María this afternoon.

additional_notes: Used when someone is speaking with themselves, either out loud or internally, usually for reflection or thinking through something.
target_language_example: Ella suele hablar consigo cuando está resolviendo un problema difícil.
native_language_example: She usually talks to herself when she is solving a difficult problem.

additional_notes: "Hablar de" is used to introduce the topic or subject someone is addressing in a conversation or discussion. It is often followed by a noun or phrase to specify what is being discussed.
target_language_example: Vamos a hablar de tus vacaciones.
native_language_example: Let's talk about your vacation.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used in contexts where one wants to either express the ability to converse in Spanish or inquire if another person can do so.
target_language_example: ¿Puedes hablar español?
native_language_example: Can you speak Spanish?

additional_notes: This phrase is used to describe the ability to communicate in the English language. It is commonly used in questions about language proficiency and in contexts where language skills are relevant.
target_language_example: ¿Puedes hablar inglés?
native_language_example: Can you speak English?

additional_notes: This is a direct question in Spanish, often used to inquire about someone's ability to communicate in English. Note that 'hablas' is the informal second person singular form, so it's used when addressing someone informally.
target_language_example: ¿Tú hablas inglés?
native_language_example: Do you speak English?

additional_notes: Typically used to set the scene for a story, especially in the context of fairy tales.
target_language_example: Había una vez un príncipe que vivía en un reino muy lejano.
native_language_example: Once upon a time, there was a prince who lived in a faraway kingdom.

additional_notes: Used to talk about something that happened a long time in the past. The phrase literally translates to "makes years" but is used to express the passage of time, similar to 'years ago' in English.
target_language_example: Hace años que no lo veo.
native_language_example: I haven't seen him in years.

additional_notes: Used to express a need for something or to say that something is lacking or required. It can be used in various situations ranging from practical needs to more abstract or emotional contexts.
target_language_example: Hace falta más tiempo para terminar el proyecto.
native_language_example: We need more time to finish the project.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe events in the past that occurred a significant time ago. It can be used in both informal and formal contexts.
target_language_example: Hace mucho que no vemos a Javier.
native_language_example: We haven't seen Javier in a long time.

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used when talking about an event or action that took place in the recent past. It can be used in various tenses to refer to something recent, like yesterday, last week, etc.
target_language_example: Llegué hace poco de mi viaje.
native_language_example: I arrived recently from my trip.

meaning: "a long time ago" or "for a while".
additional_notes: This phrase is often used to convey that something has happened or has been happening for a lengthy period before now. It's common in storytelling or when discussing events in the past.
target_language_example: Hace tiempo que no veo a María.
native_language_example: I haven't seen María in a long time.

meaning: to fail or to be weak.
additional_notes: This expression is used metaphorically to describe when something is not going well or is in the process of failing. It can be used for projects, relationships, and more.
target_language_example: El plan comenzó a hacer agua cuando perdimos el financiamiento.
native_language_example: The plan began to fail when we lost funding.

additional_notes: 'Hacer algunos años' is used when one wants to express that something happened a few years in the past without being specific. It's a casual way to discuss past events.
target_language_example: Fuimos a España hacer algunos años.
native_language_example: We went to Spain some years ago.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe the action of forming friendships. It implies the effort or initiative taken to establish friendly relationships.
target_language_example: Es importante hacer amigos cuando te mudas a un nuevo lugar.
native_language_example: It's important to make friends when you move to a new place.

additional_notes: Commonly used to express how old someone is turning. You'll often hear 'cumplir años' as a more standard expression. For example, 'Él hizo diez años' means 'He turned ten years old.'
target_language_example: Mi hermana hizo quince años la semana pasada.
native_language_example: My sister turned fifteen last week.

additional_notes: Used to convey that something is done correctly, satisfactorily, or with good results. Often used to commend someone's actions or to describe successful outcomes.
target_language_example: Lo hiciste bien en el examen.
native_language_example: You did well on the exam.

meaning: 'to do well to' or 'it's a good idea to'.
additional_notes: This phrase is often followed by an infinitive verb and implies that someone has made a sound decision or acted wisely.
target_language_example: Hiciste bien en llamar antes de venir.
native_language_example: You did well to call before coming.

additional_notes: It is a common way to describe pleasant weather, particularly sunny and warm conditions. The phrase is impersonal, using 'hacer' to denote the state of the weather.
target_language_example: Hoy hace buen tiempo para ir a la playa.
native_language_example: Today is good weather to go to the beach.

additional_notes: Typically used to describe favorable weather conditions. The verb 'hacer' is commonly used in Spanish to discuss weather by indicating 'it makes'. For weather, other versions of this phrase include 'hace buen tiempo'.
target_language_example: Hoy hace bueno, así que vamos a la playa.
native_language_example: Today it's nice weather, so we're going to the beach.

additional_notes: Used to describe the weather when it is hot, indicating the temperature in natural surroundings or climate. Often paired with expressions of time, such as days, months, or seasons.
target_language_example: En verano, suele hacer mucho calor aquí.
native_language_example: In summer, it usually gets very hot here.

meaning: to pay attention to; to heed.
additional_notes: Used when advising someone to listen to or follow instructions, guidance, or advice. Often used in contexts where ignoring someone or something might lead to consequences.
target_language_example: Deberías hacer caso a los consejos de tu madre.
native_language_example: You should pay attention to your mother's advice.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to indicate that something happened five days prior to the current day. It is commonly structured with a past tense verb to describe the action that took place.
target_language_example: Hacer cinco días que recibí esa carta.
native_language_example: I received that letter five days ago.

meaning: 'to click' (with a mouse or similar device).
additional_notes: This term is widely used in technology and computing contexts, similar to its English counterpart.
target_language_example: Haz clic en el enlace para abrir la página.
native_language_example: Click on the link to open the page.

meaning: to stand in line; to queue.
additional_notes: Used when referring to the action of forming or waiting in a line, commonly in a public place such as a store, bank, or event.
target_language_example: Tuvimos que hacer cola por una hora para entrar al concierto.
native_language_example: We had to stand in line for an hour to get into the concert.

additional_notes: Used to describe the playful action of tickling someone, which usually results in laughter. It can be used informally with friends and family.
target_language_example: A mi hermano le gusta hacerme cosquillas.
native_language_example: My brother likes to tickle me.

additional_notes: This phrase can refer to both physical injury and emotional or psychological harm. It is used to describe when something or someone causes pain or damage.
target_language_example: No quiero hacerte daño.
native_language_example: I don't want to hurt you.

additional_notes: Used to describe the act of earning or generating income, similar to the English phrase 'make money'. Often related to jobs or business activities.
target_language_example: Él trabaja duro para hacer dinero.
native_language_example: He works hard to make money.

additional_notes: The verb 'hacer' in this context is used to indicate the passage of time since an event. The time expression that follows 'hacer' can be adjusted to reflect different time frames such as hours, weeks, months, etc.
target_language_example: Hice el pedido hace dos días.
native_language_example: I placed the order two days ago.

additional_notes: Used to express the duration necessary to complete a trip or task. It's a common way to specify the amount of time required.
target_language_example: Para llegar a la ciudad, hacemos dos horas.
native_language_example: It takes us two hours to get to the city.

additional_notes:
This phrase is used to specify that something happened or was done two months prior from the current moment. In conversational Spanish, it is typical to use this structure to talk about past events or experiences 
relative to the current time frame.
target_language_example: Fui a España hacer dos meses.
native_language_example: I went to Spain two months ago.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to describe when an event occurred. It literally translates to 'make two weeks', but is understood as 'two weeks ago'.
target_language_example: Llegué aquí hace dos semanas.
native_language_example: I arrived here two weeks ago.

additional_notes: Used to describe a romantic and intimate act, typically in a respectful or affectionate context.
target_language_example: Ellos decidieron hacer el amor a la luz de las velas.
native_language_example: They decided to make love by candlelight.

meaning: to make a fool of oneself.
additional_notes: Used when someone acts in a way that causes embarrassment or is perceived as foolish.
target_language_example: No quiero hacer el ridículo en la presentación.
native_language_example: I don't want to make a fool of myself during the presentation.

meaning: to act foolishly or goof off.
additional_notes: Used to describe someone who is being playful or not serious, sometimes as a way to procrastinate or avoid responsibilities.
target_language_example: Deja de hacer el tonto y ponte a trabajar.
native_language_example: Stop goofing off and get to work.

additional_notes: This phrase often implies that someone has been caused to wait due to another's actions. It can be used in contexts where an apology is made for a delay, or when discussing plans that involve waiting.
target_language_example: Lo siento por hacerte esperar tanto.
native_language_example: I'm sorry for making you wait so long.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to express the need for something, similar to the English "I need..." or "It's necessary...". It can also be used in questions to ask if something is needed.
target_language_example: Nos hace falta más tiempo para completar el proyecto.
native_language_example: We need more time to complete the project.

additional_notes: Used to describe organizing or hosting a party or celebration. It can refer to both formal and informal gatherings.
target_language_example: Vamos a hacer fiesta este sábado.
native_language_example: We are going to have a party this Saturday.

additional_notes: Commonly used when discussing problems or challenges that need to be addressed. It's often followed by 'a' and the thing being confronted, for example, 'hacer frente a los problemas'.
target_language_example: Tuvimos que hacer frente a muchos retos.
native_language_example: We had to confront many challenges.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe the weather, similar to how we say 'it's cold' in English. The verb 'hacer' is used impersonally in this context, referring to atmospheric conditions.
target_language_example: Hoy hace mucho frío.
native_language_example: It's very cold today.

meaning: to find something funny or amusing.
additional_notes: 'Hacer gracia' is often used to express that someone finds something humorous in a lighthearted way. It can be used in various contexts where something generates amusement or entertainment.
target_language_example: Me hace gracia su manera de bailar.
native_language_example: I find her way of dancing amusing.

additional_notes: Used to describe significant achievements or events that will be remembered for a long time. Often used in contexts of accomplishments or groundbreaking situations.
target_language_example: La científica hizo historia con su descubrimiento.
native_language_example: The scientist made history with her discovery.

meaning: to be excited about; to look forward to.
additional_notes: Used when expressing anticipation or the feeling of happiness about future events. It's commonly used in both personal and professional contexts to convey positive emotions about upcoming experiences.
target_language_example: Me hace ilusión viajar a España este verano.
native_language_example: I'm excited about traveling to Spain this summer.

additional_notes: Frequently used in contexts involving fashion or home decor to describe items that complement each other well.
target_language_example: Ese cinturón hace juego con tus zapatos.
native_language_example: That belt matches your shoes.

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used in daily routine and household context. It implies tidying up the bed after use, usually in the morning.
target_language_example: Cada mañana, mi hermana hace la cama antes de ir a la escuela.
native_language_example: Every morning, my sister makes the bed before going to school.

meaning: 'to pack the suitcase' or 'to pack your bags'.
additional_notes: Used to talk about getting ready for travel by putting clothes and other items into a suitcase. It is typically used in relation to personal travel or vacation preparation.
target_language_example: Necesito hacer la maleta para el viaje de mañana.
native_language_example: I need to pack my suitcase for tomorrow's trip.

meaning: 'make a living' or 'get on with life'.
additional_notes: It refers to the activities and efforts involved in sustaining oneself or achieving personal goals. Often used to talk about work, daily routines, or adapting to circumstances.
target_language_example: Ella se fue a otra ciudad para hacer la vida.
native_language_example: She moved to another city to make a living.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used when someone is preparing for a trip and refers to the act of organizing items into luggage.
target_language_example: Tengo que hacer las maletas antes de irme al aeropuerto.
native_language_example: I need to pack my bags before going to the airport.

additional_notes: Used when resolving a conflict or dispute with someone, typically after a fight or argument, indicating a return to a state of harmony.
target_language_example: Después de la discusión, decidimos hacer las paces.
native_language_example: After the argument, we decided to make peace.

additional_notes: This phrase can be used in emotional contexts, where someone's actions or events lead to another person's tears, whether in sadness, happiness, or frustration.
target_language_example: La película hizo llorar a todos los espectadores.
native_language_example: The movie made all the viewers cry.

additional_notes: Used when referring to taking ethical, honorable, or correct actions or decisions.
target_language_example: Siempre trato de hacer lo correcto, incluso cuando es difícil.
native_language_example: I always try to do the right thing, even when it's difficult.

additional_notes: The verb 'hacer' is used in Spanish to describe many weather conditions. 'Mucho' intensifies the coldness, and 'frío' refers to cold.
target_language_example: Hoy hace mucho frío.
native_language_example: Today it is very cold.

meaning: to make a lot of noise.
additional_notes: This phrase can be used literally, describing anything from a loud conversation to noisy machines. It can also be used metaphorically, indicating that something is causing a big impact or commotion.
target_language_example: Los niños están haciendo mucho ruido en el parque.
native_language_example: The children are making a lot of noise in the park.

meaning: 'a long time ago' or 'for a long time'.
additional_notes: Used to indicate that a considerable amount of time has elapsed. Often used in past tense constructs to contextualize experiences or actions.
target_language_example: Hacer mucho tiempo que no te veo.
native_language_example: I haven't seen you in a long time.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that something occurred a long time ago. It often sets the scene or provides a time reference in a narrative.
target_language_example: Hacer muchos años, vivía en una pequeña aldea.
native_language_example: Many years ago, I lived in a small village.

additional_notes: This phrase is used when someone causes another person to pay in some way, either literally (financial payment) or metaphorically (making someone pay the consequences for an action).
target_language_example: Él le hizo pagar el daño que causó a su coche.
native_language_example: He made him pay for the damage done to his car.

additional_notes: Often used figuratively as well as literally, such as in breaking objects or in emotional contexts. Can be used to describe both physical actions or metaphorical situations.
target_language_example: El jarrón se cayó y se hizo pedazos.
native_language_example: The vase fell and broke into pieces.

additional_notes: It is an informal and child-friendly way to refer to urinating, similar to 'going to the bathroom' or 'having a wee' in English.
target_language_example: El niño necesita hacer pis antes del viaje.
native_language_example: The child needs to pee before the trip.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used when discussing the act of questioning or inquiring. It's important for learners to understand both the verb 'hacer' (to do/make) and the noun 'preguntas' (questions).
target_language_example: En clase, es importante hacer preguntas para entender mejor la lección.
native_language_example: In class, it's important to ask questions to better understand the lesson.

additional_notes: Used when you fulfill a goal or achieve something you've been working towards. It implies effort and transformation from idea to reality.
target_language_example: Con mucho esfuerzo, logrará hacer realidad su sueño de ser médico.
native_language_example: With a lot of effort, she will make her dream of becoming a doctor come true.

additional_notes: Used to describe any situation where noise is being created. It can be used both literally, in terms of physical noise, and figuratively, as in drawing attention.
target_language_example: Los niños comenzaron a hacer ruido en el parque.
native_language_example: The children started to make noise in the park.

additional_notes: Used to describe a sunny day or when the sun is shining. Common in weather-related conversations.
target_language_example: Hoy hace sol en la playa.
native_language_example: Today it's sunny at the beach.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used in contexts where someone is causing an object, like a musical instrument or a device, to emit a sound. It can also refer to triggering notifications or alarms.
target_language_example: Ella sabe cómo hacer sonar la guitarra de forma hermosa.
native_language_example: She knows how to make the guitar sound beautifully.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used in educational settings, typically by students discussing their evening plans or obligations.
target_language_example: Tengo que hacer tarea después de la escuela.
native_language_example: I have to do homework after school.

meaning: 'to do everything possible' or 'to make every effort'.
additional_notes: This phrase is used when someone is trying their best to achieve something or help out in a situation to the fullest extent of their abilities.
target_language_example: Voy a hacer todo lo posible para terminar el proyecto a tiempo.
native_language_example: I will do everything possible to finish the project on time.

additional_notes: Used to describe dishonest behavior, often in games, competitions, or in general life situations. Can also imply breaking the rules to gain an advantage.
target_language_example: Él siempre hace trampa en los juegos de cartas.
native_language_example: He always cheats at card games.

meaning: 'three months ago' or 'three months from now'.
additional_notes: The phrase is used to describe a time frame, depending on the context it can mean three months in the past or future. Often accompanied by other time markers for clarity.
target_language_example: Hace tres meses que empecé a trabajar aquí.
native_language_example: I started working here three months ago.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to measure time since an event, often translated as '(time period) ago.' It is commonly used to describe how much time has passed since something happened.
target_language_example: Hace tres semanas que fui al médico.
native_language_example: I went to the doctor three weeks ago.

additional_notes: This idiomatic phrase can describe both physical destruction and metaphorical breaking or shattering, often involving emotions or reputations.
target_language_example: El niño hizo trizas el papel que encontró.
native_language_example: The child tore the paper he found to pieces.

additional_notes: Commonly used in a work context to refer to working overtime or putting in extra work hours. It can be part of a conversation about work schedules or specific projects.
target_language_example: Hoy tengo que hacer unas horas en la oficina.
native_language_example: Today I have to work a few extra hours at the office.

additional_notes: Commonly used in informal speech to refer to actions that happened in the recent past. Typically followed by a verb in the past tense.
target_language_example: Vi a Juan hace unos días.
native_language_example: I saw Juan a few days ago.

additional_notes: Used to describe when there is wind blowing, typically referring to the current or forecasted weather conditions.
target_language_example: Hoy va a hacer viento en la playa.
native_language_example: Today it's going to be windy at the beach.

additional_notes: Commonly used in instructions or descriptions to explain the manner or tool with which an action is performed. Conjugate 'hacer' according to the context for formal or informal situations.
target_language_example: Voy a hacerlo con cuidado.
native_language_example: I am going to do it carefully.

additional_notes: Used for changes that are seen as voluntary or the result of effort: hacerse médico (to become a doctor). Contrast with "ponerse" (temporary states) and "volverse" (involuntary changes).
target_language_example: Se hizo vegetariano el año pasado.
native_language_example: He became vegetarian last year.

additional_notes: This phrase is used when someone is going to be responsible for managing or handling a situation or task. It emphasizes the action of assuming responsibility or taking control of a situation.
target_language_example: Debo hacerme cargo de la situación ahora mismo.
native_language_example: I must take responsibility for the situation right now.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to describe the transition from daylight to nighttime. It's often used in conversations about time, routines, or schedules, when someone wants to indicate that it is becoming nighttime.
target_language_example: Vamos a volver antes de que se haga de noche.
native_language_example: Let's return before it gets dark.

additional_notes: This phrase is used when someone pretends not to know or understand something intentionally. It often implies that the person is doing this to avoid responsibility or get out of a situation.
target_language_example: Pedro se hizo el tonto cuando le preguntaron sobre el proyecto.
native_language_example: Pedro played dumb when he was asked about the project.

additional_notes: Used to indicate someone is being overly optimistic or expecting something unrealistic to happen.
target_language_example: No te hagas ilusiones con ese trabajo, es muy difícil conseguirlo.
native_language_example: Don't get your hopes up about that job; it's very difficult to get it.

meaning: to pose as or pretend to be.
additional_notes: This phrase is often used when someone is making others believe they are someone else, either as a deception or disguise.
target_language_example: El detective se hizo pasar por vendedor para obtener información.
native_language_example: The detective posed as a salesman to gather information.

additional_notes: Commonly used in informal settings, especially when talking to or about children. It softens the act of urination, making it more suitable for casual conversation.
target_language_example: El niño se hizo pis en la cama.
native_language_example: The child wet the bed.

additional_notes: This phrase implies that someone wins affection or admiration through deliberate actions or charming behavior, making others like or love them.
target_language_example: Ella siempre está ayudando a los demás, no es de extrañar que se haga querer por todos.
native_language_example: She is always helping others, no wonder she makes herself loved by everyone.

additional_notes: The phrase is used to indicate the passage of time, especially when one realizes that it is later than expected or planned. It is often used when one needs to hurry or when it's realized that an earlier time is now late.
target_language_example: Se está haciendo tarde, debemos irnos.
native_language_example: It's getting late, we should leave.

meaning: to fall apart; to be shattered
additional_notes: This phrase can be used literally, as in when an object breaks into pieces, or figuratively, to describe emotions being torn apart. It's a way to express a profound level of destruction or ruin.
target_language_example: Después de la triste noticia, mi corazón se hizo trizas.
native_language_example: After the sad news, my heart was shattered.

additional_notes: Often used to describe physical movement or location in a downward direction. Similar to the English phrases "going down" or "facing downwards."
target_language_example: El agua fluye hacia abajo por la colina.
native_language_example: The water flows downhill.

additional_notes: Used when a speaker wants to indicate movement or direction toward where they are currently located, often when giving directions or pointing something out.
target_language_example: ¿Puedes llevarlo hacia acá, por favor?
native_language_example: Can you bring it over here, please?

additional_notes: It is often used to talk about the direction of movement, similar to saying 'this way' in English, indicating a path or motion in the speaker's direction.
target_language_example: Ella viene hacia aquí.
native_language_example: She is coming towards here.

additional_notes: It is often used in directions, instructions, or to describe the movement of a person or object. It indicates movement or direction from a lower point to a higher point.
target_language_example: El ascensor va hacia arriba.
native_language_example: The elevator is going upwards.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to describe movement in the opposite direction from where you are facing or oriented, similar to 'backward' in English. It can apply to both physical movements and metaphorical references, such as thinking about the past.
target_language_example: El coche se movió hacia atrás.
native_language_example: The car moved backward.

additional_notes: Used to point out direction or to ask someone to come, look, or move closer to where the speaker is.
target_language_example: Por favor, coloque la caja hacia este lado.
native_language_example: Please place the box this way.

additional_notes: The term is commonly used to convey that something has been true, consistent, or ongoing up to the present moment.
target_language_example: Todo ha ido bien hasta ahora.
native_language_example: Everything has gone well until now.

additional_notes: This phrase can be used in both physical contexts, like reaching a physical location or limit, or metaphorically when referring to understanding, patience, or any kind of limiting factor in situations.
target_language_example: Caminamos juntos hasta ahí.
native_language_example: We walked together up to there.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to indicate a physical destination or to express reaching a limit, either emotionally or situationally. It can imply frustration when used in expressions like 'I'm fed up'.
target_language_example: He trabajado hasta aquí y necesito un descanso.
native_language_example: I've worked up to here and need a break.

meaning: 'to some extent' or 'up to a certain point'.
additional_notes: Used to express partial agreement or a limited degree of something. It often implies that there's a limit to the statement being made.
target_language_example: Estoy de acuerdo contigo hasta cierto punto.
native_language_example: I agree with you to some extent.

additional_notes: Commonly used in informal settings, this phrase doesn't specify an exact meeting time but suggests an intention to meet again or that someone will see another at a later, unidentified time.
target_language_example: Nos vemos, hasta después.
native_language_example: See you, see you later.

additional_notes: Used to ask about limits, boundaries, or how much something is known or understood. It can indicate an inquiry about the farthest point or the complete extent to which something reaches.
target_language_example: ¿Hasta dónde puedes nadar sin descanso?
native_language_example: How far can you swim without stopping?

additional_notes: Literally “up to the ass.” Used colloquially to stress that something is at its limit: a crowded place, or your patience. Often appears after “estar” plus “de + noun/verb.” Comparable to “up to my eyeballs/ass” or “sick to death of.”
target_language_example: Estoy hasta el culo de trabajo esta semana.
native_language_example: I'm totally fed up with work this week.

additional_notes: Used to stress an intense or all-encompassing feeling (cold, fatigue, love, hatred, etc.). Comparable to saying someone is affected "to their core."
target_language_example: Estaba mojado hasta el tuétano después de la tormenta.
native_language_example: I was soaked to the bone after the storm.

additional_notes: Used to express the anticipation of meeting or engaging again at a specified future time; often used when parting ways until a future time.
target_language_example: Nos vemos en la fiesta, ¡hasta entonces!
native_language_example: See you at the party, until then!

additional_notes: Frequently used to talk about events or facts that remained valid or were ongoing up to the current day. It can also imply that things might change after today.
target_language_example: He trabajado aquí hasta hoy.
native_language_example: I have worked here until today.

additional_notes: Often used to imply an intention to meet or see someone again later at night. It can be a casual way to say goodbye, similar to 'see you tonight'.
target_language_example: Voy a trabajar hasta la noche.
native_language_example: I will work until the night.

meaning: “until next time; see you next time.”
additional_notes: Informal farewell similar to “see you later.” You can add "vez" (time) after it: "hasta la próxima vez."
target_language_example: Gracias por venir, ¡hasta la próxima!
native_language_example: Thanks for coming, see you next time!

meaning: (vulgar) completely fed up / at one’s limit.
additional_notes: Very strong Mexican slang—avoid in formal or polite situations. Often appears with the verb "estar": "estar hasta la verga de…" to say you’re utterly sick of something; or describing a place packed with people: "Está hasta la verga de gente."
target_language_example: ¡Estoy hasta la verga de este trabajo!
native_language_example: I’m totally fed up with this job!

additional_notes: Very informal. Often follows the verb "estar" plus "de" to state what one is full of/obsessed with: "Estoy hasta las trancas de..." Most common sense is being passionately in love.
target_language_example: Está hasta las trancas de Ana.
native_language_example: He’s head over heels for Ana.

additional_notes: An idiom stressing that an emotion, condition, or effect is felt very deeply or completely. Common with verbs like estar (to be) or calar (to soak).
target_language_example: Estoy enamorado hasta los tuétanos.
native_language_example: I’m in love to the core.

additional_notes: This phrase is used as a friendly and informal way to say goodbye when you expect to see someone again later.
target_language_example: Nos vemos, ¡hasta luego!
native_language_example: See you, see you later!

additional_notes: This phrase is typically used when you're saying goodbye to someone and expect to see them the following day. It can be used in both formal and informal contexts.
target_language_example: Nos vemos en el trabajo, ¡hasta mañana!
native_language_example: See you at work, see you tomorrow!

additional_notes: This phrase is used to describe a situation that will remain as it is until an update is provided. It is commonly used in official or formal contexts.
target_language_example: La oficina permanecerá cerrada hasta nuevo aviso.
native_language_example: The office will remain closed until further notice.

additional_notes: It is often used with verbs in the subjunctive mood when referring to a future event or situation that hasn't occurred yet. In contrast, for events that are considered habitual or already happened, the indicative mood is used.
target_language_example: Voy a esperar aquí hasta que llegues.
native_language_example: I will wait here until you arrive.

additional_notes: Used to express reaching a certain limit or degree in a situation or action. Often introduces a cause or consequence.
target_language_example: Estaba tan cansado que se quedó dormido hasta tal punto que ni siquiera escuchó el despertador.
native_language_example: He was so tired that he fell asleep to the extent that he didn't even hear the alarm clock.

additional_notes: Use 'hasta tú' to express that someone is involved in something, often with a note of surprise or emphasis, implying that inclusion is noteworthy.
target_language_example: Hasta tú entendiste la broma.
native_language_example: Even you understood the joke.

additional_notes: Always followed by an infinitive and has no explicit subject; expresses a general obligation that applies to anyone in context.
target_language_example: Hay que estudiar para el examen.
native_language_example: One must study for the exam.

additional_notes: Used to calm a situation, often in tense or argumentative contexts. Common in informal settings to diffuse tension.
target_language_example: Por favor, todos, haya paz durante la reunión.
native_language_example: Please, everyone, let there be peace during the meeting.

additional_notes: This phrase can be used to give someone the freedom to decide their actions. It might be used supportively or sometimes with a hint of indifference, depending on the context.
target_language_example: Si quieres, haz lo que quieras esta tarde.
native_language_example: If you want, do what you want this afternoon.

additional_notes: Used to point out or present something, often in a formal or literary context.
target_language_example: He aquí las pruebas que necesitas.
native_language_example: Here are the proofs you need.

additional_notes: Used to describe products that are made using skill or art by hand, not mass-produced by machines.
target_language_example: Compré unas cerámicas preciosas que son hechas a mano.
native_language_example: I bought some beautiful ceramics that are handmade.

additional_notes: This expression is generally considered vulgar and highly offensive. It's used to insult someone by indirectly insulting their mother. In Spanish-speaking cultures, insults involving family members can be particularly serious.
target_language_example: ¡Esa mujer es una hija de puta!
native_language_example: That woman is a daughter of a b****!

additional_notes: Used to describe a girl who does not have brothers or sisters. The male equivalent is 'hijo único' for 'only son'.
target_language_example: Ella es hija única en su familia.
native_language_example: She is the only daughter in her family.

additional_notes: This expression is a strong insult in Spanish and should be used with caution. It reflects anger or disdain towards someone.
target_language_example: ¡Ese hombre me robó el bolso, qué hijo de perra!
native_language_example: That man stole my bag, what a son of a bitch!

additional_notes: This is a strong insult and should be used with caution. It can refer to someone you are extremely angry with; however, in some contexts, it might be used among friends in a jocular or teasing manner, though this depends heavily on tone and familiarity.
target_language_example: ¡Ese hombre es un hijo de puta!
native_language_example: That man is a son of a bitch!

additional_notes: Often used by parents speaking to their sons in a loving or comforting manner. Can also be used metaphorically to express care or concern for someone younger or for someone you feel responsible for. It has a warm and affectionate connotation.
target_language_example: Ven aquí, hijo mío, vamos a hablar.
native_language_example: Come here, my son, let's talk.

additional_notes: This term is used to describe a child who does not have siblings. "Hijo" means "son", but "hijo único" is gender-neutral in the sense that it can be used for any only child. "Hija única" is used specifically for girls.
target_language_example: Ella es una hija única.
native_language_example: She is an only child.

additional_notes: It's used for cleaning between teeth and ensuring oral hygiene.
target_language_example: Por favor, pásame el hilo dental.
native_language_example: Please pass me the dental floss.

additional_notes: It is usually played or sung during national holidays, official events, and sports gatherings to evoke patriotic feelings.
target_language_example: Todos se pusieron de pie mientras tocaba el himno nacional.
native_language_example: Everyone stood up while the national anthem was playing.

additional_notes: This term is used to describe a male who is involved in business activities, often focusing on someone who owns or leads a business or has a high-level position in commerce.
target_language_example: Juan es un exitoso hombre de negocios.
native_language_example: Juan is a successful businessman.

additional_notes: Used to describe someone who is worldly, experienced, or cosmopolitan.
target_language_example: Él es un verdadero hombre del mundo, siempre viajando y conociendo diferentes culturas.
native_language_example: He is a true man of the world, always traveling and learning about different cultures.

additional_notes: Refers to a mythical creature or character that can transform between a human and a wolf, often popular in horror literature and films.
target_language_example: Anoche, en la película, vimos a un hombre lobo aterrador.
native_language_example: Last night, in the movie, we saw a terrifying werewolf.

additional_notes: Used literally to refer to a deceased male or metaphorically in expressions or warnings, e.g., describing someone in great trouble or danger.
target_language_example: El hombre muerto yacía en el suelo del bosque.
native_language_example: The dead man lay on the forest floor.

additional_notes: Used when referring to a critical or decisive point that will reveal the outcome or truth of a situation.
target_language_example: El examen final será la hora de la verdad para los estudiantes.
native_language_example: The final exam will be the moment of truth for the students.

additional_notes: Used to describe the periods in a day when traffic is heaviest, typically when people are traveling to or from work.
target_language_example: Siempre intento evitar viajar durante la hora punta porque el tráfico es terrible.
native_language_example: I always try to avoid traveling during rush hour because the traffic is terrible.

additional_notes: Used to discuss contemporary trends, conditions, or situations. Can be synonymous with 'actualmente' or 'en estos días'.
target_language_example: Hoy día, muchas personas usan internet para trabajar desde casa.
native_language_example: Nowadays, many people use the internet to work from home.

additional_notes: Used to describe things that happen or are true in the present time, especially when comparing with how things were in the past.
target_language_example: Hoy en día, la tecnología avanza muy rápido.
native_language_example: Nowadays, technology progresses very quickly.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to indicate that something will happen or should happen on the current day, often implying urgency or a need for immediate action.
target_language_example: Voy a terminar el informe hoy mismo.
native_language_example: I am going to finish the report today itself.

additional_notes: Used to emphasize that something is so evident or known to listeners that it barely needs stating. Commonly used in both spoken and written Spanish.
target_language_example: Huelga decir que la seguridad es nuestra prioridad principal.
native_language_example: It goes without saying that safety is our main priority.

additional_notes: Used to refer to the unique pattern of a fingerprint or metaphorically to uniqueness, identity, or digital footprint in technological contexts.
target_language_example: Los detectives encontraron una huella digital en la escena del crimen.
native_language_example: The detectives found a fingerprint at the crime scene.

additional_notes: It refers to an egg that has been cooked, typically in boiling water. Commonly found in breakfast contexts or in salads.
target_language_example: Me gusta comer huevo cocido para el desayuno.
native_language_example: I like to eat a boiled egg for breakfast.

additional_notes: Often used when purchasing tickets or describing travel plans, particularly with transport like trains, buses, or planes.
target_language_example: Compré un billete de ida y vuelta a Madrid.
native_language_example: I bought a round trip ticket to Madrid.

additional_notes: Refers to any language that is not the native language of the speaker or the country. Commonly used in contexts such as education, self-improvement, or travel.
target_language_example: Estoy aprendiendo un idioma extranjero.
native_language_example: I am learning a foreign language.

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used in conversations to express that you feel the same way about something that was just stated by someone else.
target_language_example: Si estás cansado, igual conmigo.
native_language_example: If you're tired, same with me.

additional_notes: This expression is used to convey that something does not matter at all to the speaker. It is considered informal and may be offensive or inappropriate in certain contexts, similar to the English expression 'not to give a damn'.
target_language_example: No me importa un carajo lo que digan.
native_language_example: I don't give a damn what they say.

additional_notes: Usually refers to uncontrolled fires that occur in forested areas, causing damage to the environment and wildlife.
target_language_example: El incendio forestal destruyó miles de hectáreas de bosque.
native_language_example: The forest fire destroyed thousands of acres of forest.

additional_notes: It is commonly used to indicate that something is true or remains the same no matter what conditions or factors are in question.
target_language_example: Independientemente de lo que digan, yo seguiré adelante con mis planes.
native_language_example: Regardless of what they say, I will go ahead with my plans.

additional_notes: This term encompasses a wide range of devices used to produce music. Common instruments included are guitar, piano, drums, and many others.
target_language_example: El piano es mi instrumento musical favorito.
native_language_example: The piano is my favorite musical instrument.

additional_notes: Ir is an irregular verb. Present tense: voy, vas, va, vamos, vais, van. Combined with "a" + infinitive, it expresses the near future (e.g., "voy a comer" = "I’m going to eat").
target_language_example: Mañana voy al mercado.
native_language_example: Tomorrow I’m going to the market.

meaning: to go to / to be going to (+ verb).
additional_notes: Used with a place noun to show physical movement, or with an infinitive verb to express the near future (similar to English "going to" do something). Conjugate "ir" and keep "a" unchanged.
target_language_example: Mañana voy a estudiar para el examen.
native_language_example: Tomorrow I’m going to study for the exam.

meaning: 'to go and fetch' or 'to go and get'.
additional_notes: This phrase is often used when someone needs to physically go to another location to retrieve something or someone.
target_language_example: Voy a ir a buscar el coche al taller.
native_language_example: I'm going to fetch the car from the workshop.

additional_notes: Commonly used to refer to attending a Catholic church service, ‘ir a misa’ can imply both the physical act of attending and the spiritual or communal significance. It is often used in the context of discussing weekly or special occasion church attendance.
target_language_example: Los domingos, mi familia y yo vamos a ir a misa.
native_language_example: On Sundays, my family and I are going to go to mass.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to talk about an action or state that will occur in the future. It is the future periphrasis in Spanish, similar to 'going to' in English.
target_language_example: Este año va a ser muy emocionante.
native_language_example: This year is going to be very exciting.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to indicate moving forward physically or metaphorically, such as in a process or plan.
target_language_example: El equipo decidió ir adelante con el proyecto.
native_language_example: The team decided to go forward with the project.

additional_notes: Often used in conversations when someone wants another person to focus on the main issue or subject. It translates literally as 'to go to the grain,' which metaphorically implies skipping over the extras and addressing the core message directly.
target_language_example: Vamos a ir al grano, ¿cuál es el problema?
native_language_example: Let's get to the point, what is the issue?

additional_notes: Used to indicate movement towards a specific place that is relatively distant from the current location. It often suggests a journey or an intention to reach a particular point.
target_language_example: ¿Quieres ir allá mañana?
native_language_example: Do you want to go there tomorrow?

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to describe physical movement upwards, such as going upstairs, climbing a hill, or moving to a higher level.
target_language_example: Voy a ir arriba para ver si ya llegó el paquete.
native_language_example: I'm going to go upstairs to see if the package has arrived.

additional_notes: Used to describe someone going somewhere accompanied by someone else or taking something along, often followed by a noun or pronoun to indicate who or what the accompaniment is.
target_language_example: Voy a ir con mis amigos al cine.
native_language_example: I'm going to go to the movies with my friends.

additional_notes: This structure is often followed by an activity or location noun, such as 'compras' (shopping) or 'vacaciones' (vacation), indicating going for that activity or trip.
target_language_example: Vamos a ir de compras mañana.
native_language_example: We're going shopping tomorrow.

additional_notes: This phrase is typically used when one is planning to shop for clothes, groceries, or other items. It's often used in casual conversation. The verb 'ir' is conjugated to match the subject, e.g., 'Voy de compras' (I go shopping).
target_language_example: Vamos de compras al centro comercial.
native_language_example: Let's go shopping at the mall.

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used metaphorically to describe two concepts or actions that complement each other or happen together, such as teamwork or features that complement each other.
target_language_example: El éxito y el trabajo duro van de la mano.
native_language_example: Success and hard work go hand in hand.

meaning: to go too far or to overstep boundaries.
additional_notes: The phrase is often used when someone has crossed an acceptable line, either by saying or doing something inappropriate. It can be used in both personal and professional contexts.
target_language_example: Creo que estás empezando a ir demasiado lejos con tus críticas.
native_language_example: I think you're starting to go too far with your criticisms.

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used when giving directions or stating intended movement. It emphasizes directionality and can be used with various destinations or goals, such as places or abstract objectives.
target_language_example: Voy a ir hacia el mercado.
native_language_example: I am going to go towards the market.

additional_notes: This phrase indicates someone is expected to arrive after the planned or expected time. It can be used in various contexts such as appointments, meetings, or casual meetups.
target_language_example: Voy a ir tarde a la reunión.
native_language_example: I am going to be late to the meeting.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to describe the hustle and bustle or the routine movements in daily life.
target_language_example: Entre el ir y venir del trabajo, apenas tengo tiempo para descansar.
native_language_example: Between the coming and going of work, I hardly have time to rest.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to express urgency or immediacy in telling someone to go or leave right away.
target_language_example: Debes ir ya si quieres llegar a tiempo.
native_language_example: You should go now if you want to arrive on time.

additional_notes: Often used to describe how situations or events turn out for someone, indicating success, happiness, or general well-being. It implies a personal aspect of well-being specifically tied to outcomes or experiences.
target_language_example: A Juan le va bien en su nuevo trabajo.
native_language_example: Juan is doing well at his new job.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that someone is departing from the current place. Conjugates like ‘ir’ but always with reflexive pronouns (me, te, se, nos, os, se). More common in speech than ‘salir’ when simply announcing you’re heading out.
target_language_example: Ya es tarde; me voy a casa.
native_language_example: It’s late; I’m heading home.

meaning: to leave for / to go (away) to
additional_notes: Reflexive verb indicating departure + destination. Conjugate irse and add the preposition a before the place (Me voy a casa = I’m going home).
target_language_example: Mañana me voy a Madrid.
native_language_example: Tomorrow I’m leaving for Madrid.

additional_notes: Used when someone is going to sleep or rest, not just lying down on a bed.
target_language_example: Me voy a ir a la cama temprano esta noche.
native_language_example: I'm going to go to bed early tonight.

additional_notes: This phrase is used in informal, often heated situations when someone wants to strongly dismiss or show frustration towards an individual or circumstance. It is considered vulgar and should be used with caution.
target_language_example: Si no te gusta, pues ¡vete al carajo!
native_language_example: If you don't like it, then go to hell!

meaning: to leave or go away from a place.
additional_notes: The verb 'irse' is reflexive and often used with 'de' to indicate leaving a specific location or situation. It's important to conjugate the verb according to the subject.
target_language_example: Voy a irme de la fiesta temprano.
native_language_example: I'm going to leave the party early.

meaning: 'to get out of hand' or 'to lose control'.
additional_notes: Used to describe a situation that is becoming uncontrollable or has escalated beyond one's ability to manage.
target_language_example: El proyecto se nos fue de las manos por falta de organización.
native_language_example: The project got out of hand due to lack of organization.

additional_notes: This term is used to declare the end of a chess game when a player's king is in a position to be captured and there are no legal moves to escape the threat. It's often used metaphorically to denote a conclusive or decisive action in other contexts as well.
target_language_example: Y con esa jugada, es jaque mate.
native_language_example: And with that move, it's checkmate.

additional_notes: Used to describe activities primarily based on luck, such as lottery or casino games, rather than skill or strategy.
target_language_example: El póker es un juego de azar popular en el casino.
native_language_example: Poker is a popular game of chance in the casino.

additional_notes: Used to refer to games played on a flat surface involving pieces or cards, often for fun or competition.
target_language_example: Me gusta jugar al juego de mesa en familia los domingos.
native_language_example: I like playing board games with my family on Sundays.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to describe a task or activity that is considered very simple or easy to accomplish, much like the English equivalent. It often implies that the task is so simple that even a child could do it.
target_language_example: Para él, resolver ese problema es un juego de niños.
native_language_example: For him, solving that problem is child's play.

additional_notes: Refers to a clever or humorous use of language where multiple meanings or similar-sounding words create a comedic or rhetorical effect.
target_language_example: El comediante hizo un juego de palabras muy ingenioso.
native_language_example: The comedian made a very clever pun.

additional_notes: Primarily used in the context of sports to describe actions that violate the spirit of fair competition, but can also apply to unfair tactics in non-sport contexts.
target_language_example: El árbitro sacó tarjeta amarilla por el juego sucio.
native_language_example: The referee gave a yellow card for the dirty play.

additional_notes: Used to describe someone who collaborates well with others, supports their team, and is essential for group success.
target_language_example: Ana es un verdadero jugador de equipo, siempre ayuda a sus compañeros.
native_language_example: Ana is a true team player, she always helps her teammates.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to describe the action of engaging in games involving playing cards. It is often used in casual conversations about hobbies and leisure activities.
target_language_example: Nos gusta jugar a las cartas los fines de semana.
native_language_example: We like to play cards on the weekends.

additional_notes: Often used to describe physical location, such as being next to a building, or closeness in a metaphorical sense, like being with someone in spirit.
target_language_example: El libro está junto a la lámpara.
native_language_example: The book is next to the lamp.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that someone or something is accompanying or is included with another.
target_language_example: Ella fue al cine junto con sus amigos.
native_language_example: She went to the cinema along with her friends.

additional_notes: Used to describe something that occurs or is completed exactly at the right moment, without delay or wastage of time.
target_language_example: Llegué justo a tiempo para la reunión.
native_language_example: I arrived just in time for the meeting.

additional_notes: This expression conveys a sense of immediacy and is used to refer to an event or action happening at the present moment.
target_language_example: Llegué justo ahora al trabajo.
native_language_example: I just arrived at work right now.

additional_notes: Used to emphasize the exactness of a location. It can refer to a physical location or metaphorically a point in time or situation.
target_language_example: Coloca el libro justo ahí.
native_language_example: Put the book right there.

additional_notes: This phrase is straightforward as it directly refers to the musical instrument known as the flute in English. Useful in contexts like music lessons or discussions about musical preferences.
target_language_example: Ella toca la flauta en la orquesta.
native_language_example: She plays the flute in the orchestra.

meaning: literally 'the host', used as an exclamation for emphasis.
additional_notes: This phrase is highly informal and can be seen as vulgar. It can mean something is amazing when used positively, or express frustration or disbelief when negative, similar to 'damn' or 'hell' in English.
target_language_example: ¡Esto es la hostia!
native_language_example: This is amazing!

additional_notes: Apart from its literal meaning referring to the dairy product, 'la leche' can also be used colloquially to express surprise or as a slang term for something amazing or intense. Context is key to understanding its intended meaning.
target_language_example: Voy a comprar la leche en el supermercado.
native_language_example: I'm going to buy the milk at the supermarket.

additional_notes: Though 'el mar' is more commonly used, 'la mar' can appear in poetic or sentimental contexts, especially in literature and among people close to the sea, like fishermen.
target_language_example: El anciano pescador amaba la mar con toda su alma.
native_language_example: The old fisherman loved the sea with all his soul.

la pelota está en el tejado

target_language_multi_word_term: la pelota está en el tejado
meaning: the ball is in (your) court; it’s someone else’s turn to act.
additional_notes: Used to say responsibility or decision-making now rests with another person. Common in discussions, negotiations, or when passing the next step to someone else.
target_language_example: Te envié el contrato; ahora la pelota está en tu tejado.
native_language_example: I sent you the contract; now the ball is in your court.

additional_notes: Very informal and vulgar. Common in Spanish internet culture or among friends, but not suitable for polite or professional situations.
target_language_example: ¡Esta fiesta está siendo la polla en vinagre!
native_language_example: This party is absolutely awesome!

additional_notes: Used to refer to one’s existence, lifestyle, or life in general. Appears in many idioms (e.g., "así es la vida" – "that’s life").
target_language_example: La vida es bella.
native_language_example: Life is beautiful.

additional_notes: This expression is used to emphasize the importance of enjoying life and not wasting time, as life is considered to be fleeting and temporary.
target_language_example: Recuerda que la vida es breve y hay que disfrutar cada momento.
native_language_example: Remember that life is short and you should enjoy every moment.

additional_notes: In the right context, 'la vieja' can be affectionately used to talk about someone's mother but it can also be considered derogatory depending on tone and situation. It's important to be cautious with this term and understand the context in which it is used.
target_language_example: Voy a visitar a la vieja este fin de semana.
native_language_example: I'm going to visit the old lady this weekend.

additional_notes: This term highlights the beneficial or positive aspect of something. It's often used in expressions like 'ver el lado bueno', meaning 'to look at the bright side'.
target_language_example: Siempre trato de ver el lado bueno de las cosas.
native_language_example: I always try to see the good side of things.
